  ### Pull Request Instructions

  -   Please use the following PR title format:
  "chore: fix JavaScript lint errors (issue #<ISSUE_NUMBER>)".
  -   Reference this issue in the "Related Issues" section of the PR body as "resolves #<ISSUE_NUMBER>".
comments:
# :wave: Important: PLEASE READ :wave:

This issue has been labeled as a **good first issue** and is available for anyone to work on.

If this is your first time contributing to an open source project, some aspects of the development process may seem unusual, arcane, or some combination of both.

1.  **You cannot "claim" issues.** People new to open source often want to "claim" or be assigned an issue before beginning work. The typical rationale is that people want to avoid wasted work in the event that someone else ends up working the issue. However, this practice is not effective in open source, as it often leads to "issue squatting", in which an individual asks to be assigned, is granted their request, and then never ends up working on the issue. Accordingly, you are encouraged to communicate your intent to address this issue, ideally by providing a rough outline as to how you plan to address the issue or asking clarifying questions, but, at the end of the day, we will take running code and rough consensus in order to move forward quickly.
2.  **We have a very high bar for contributions.** We have very high standards for contributions and expect all contributions???whether new features, tests, or documentation???to be rigorous, thorough, and complete. Once a pull request is merged into stdlib, that contribution immediately becomes the collective responsibility of all maintainers of stdlib. When we merge code into stdlib, we are saying that we, the maintainers, commit to reviewing subsequent changes and making bugfixes to the code. Hence, in order to ensure future maintainability, this naturally leads to a higher standard of contribution.

Before working on this issue and opening a pull request, please read the project's [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.md). These guidelines and the associated [development guide](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/blob/develop/docs/contributing/development.md) provide important information, including links to stdlib's [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/blob/develop/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md), license policy, and steps for setting up your local development environment.

To reiterate, we **strongly** encourage you to refer to our contributing guides **before** beginning work on this issue. Failure to follow our guidelines significantly decreases the likelihood that you'll successfully contribute to stdlib and may result in automatic closure of a pull request without review.

Setting up your local development environment is a critical first step, as doing so ensures that automated development processes for linting, license verification, and unit testing can run prior to authoring commits and pushing changes. If you would prefer to avoid manual setup, we provide pre-configured [development containers](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/tree/develop/.devcontainer) for use locally or in GitHub Codespaces.

We place a high value on consistency throughout the stdlib codebase. We encourage you to closely examine other packages in stdlib and attempt to emulate the practices and conventions found therein.

-   If you are attempting to contribute a new package, sometimes the best approach is to simply copy the contents of an existing package and then modify the minimum amount necessary to implement the feature (e.g., changing descriptions, parameter names, and implementation).
-   If you are contributing tests, find a package implementing a similar feature and emulate the tests of that package.
-   If you are updating documentation, examine several similar packages and emulate the content, style, and prose of those packages.

In short, the more effort you put in to ensure that your contribution looks and feels like stdlib???including variables names, bracket spacing, line breaks, etc???the more likely that your contribution will be reviewed and ultimately accepted. We encourage you to closely study the codebase **before** beginning work on this issue.

:sparkles: Thank you again for your interest in stdlib, and we look forward to reviewing your future contributions. :sparkles:

issueDTO.title: Enable `fs.test.gr` in stdlib test suite.
issueDTO.description:
Currently, the `fs` test suite is disabled. I noticed in #2319 that it was disabled, but it seems we don't handle the cleanup of the artifacts it creates properly, so I kept it disabled for now. 


This should be pretty easy to rectify theoretically, the test suite should clean itself up however, if it fails early, it doesn't do that. 


I think what we should do is label all the temporary files `*.temp.*`, add `*.temp.*` to our gitignore list so we are not accidentally committing these if the test suite fails halfway and then clean up these `*.temp.*` files in `test-data` by reading the files in the directory and wiping them. 

If we just wipe them from the test suite and the test suite was stopped early, they could accidentally get commited. 

I was also seeing an issue where the suite was timing out, but I didn't take the time to investigate.

issueDTO.title: [DOC] The example notebook on data simulation is missing "missing data"
issueDTO.description: We have a notebook for showing examples of data simulations in discrete Bayesian Networks at: https://github.com/pgmpy/pgmpy/blob/dev/examples/Simulating_Data.ipynb. However, examples of simulating different types of missing data are missing. We need to update the notebook to include such examples as well.
comments:
I want to confirm my understanding regarding this issue. 
From what I see, we would want to give 3 types of missing data cases:
- MCR (e.g. where variable is missing with fixed randomness)
- MAR (e.g. where variable is missing depending on its own actual value)
- MNAR (e.g. where variable is missing depending on some other random variable which is not part of the model/unobserved)
(would we also want one example where the variable is missing depending on its own value and another variable that is part of the model?)

For each, we could compare with return_full to see the proportion of missing values by type of actual value. I am not completely sure about the theory yet, but I imagine the observation in MCR and MNAR for this measurement would be similar.

@Musab1Blaser 

> would we also want one example where the variable is missing depending on its own value and another variable that is part of the model?

That would be nice.

> I am not completely sure about the theory yet, but I imagine the observation in MCR and MNAR for this measurement would be similar.

It would be similar, but it would be hard to say what proportion of the values would be missing by just looking at the CPDs in the  `missing_prob` argument. We will need to run some inference over the model to find the expected proportion. I would avoid doing this in the tutorial. It could be a potentially good test case, though.

Cool
I'll start working on it :D

The commenters are discussing the details of the missing data cases, such as comparing the proportion of missing values by type of actual value, and the need to run inference over the model to find the expected proportion.

issueDTO.title: No Code - New tab opens in different panel
issueDTO.description: ### Feature description At the moment, when you press the pencil icon on the topology, it opens a no code tab on the same panel as the topology. I could see a world where the topology is always displayed, and no code editor tabs open around it. Same applies for opening a task tab from the no code menu. Allow that to continue to show, and open it as a new tab in a different panel. This would be best as an option in editor settings. Curious what others think of this idea - allowing the topology view / No-code main tab to stay present and all the additional tabs for tasks, inputs etc to open to the side. Future idea to be discussed internally: This could be expanded further where the topology view displays more of the things inside of the no-code editor too, like inputs, plugin defaults etc as no-code is a very visual type of building.
comments: Hey @wrussell1999 i would like to work on this issue could you please assign it to me?

Hi @wrussell1999 I would love to solve this issue, could you please assign to me
.

Hi @wrussell1999 
This is an interesting enhancement idea! I???d like to take this up and implement the option in the editor settings to allow keeping the topology view always visible, with new no-code tabs (like tasks or inputs) opening alongside it instead of replacing the current panel.

Please assign this issue to me ??? I???d be happy to explore and prototype this behavior.

Thanks!
Hey @ItsMeIshan, are there any updates on this?

Hi @MilosPaunovic I???m currently exploring ways to make this behavior configurable through editor settings so users can toggle between the existing setup and the proposed persistent-topology mode. In case this approach introduces complexity or conflicts with the current layout management, we can proceed with the simpler implementation as described in the issue (opening related tabs around the topology).

Hi @Piyush-r-bhaskar , I???m unable to effectively contribute to this issue as running the project containers is consuming most of my system???s RAM, making it difficult to work smoothly. To avoid any further delays, you can assign this issue to someone else.

issueDTO.title: Add a Note on a Resource Showing `last_updated` Date

On a given resource, we should display (in the top-right corner, for example) the date of the last accepted change for that resource.

issueDTO.title: Path api should not mutate paths
issueDTO.description:
```
local root = path.join("abc", "def")
-- abc/def
local alphaDir = path.join(root, "alpha")
-- abc/def/alpha
local betaDir = path.join(root, "beta")
-- abc/def/alpha/beta, expected abc/def/beta
```

`path.join` should not mutate the original path object, instead it should return a new one.

issueDTO.title: Confusing behavior when loading the record page for a non-existent record
issueDTO.description: ## Steps to reproduce 1. Open the schema page for an existing schema. Then hack the URL, changing the schema id to a value you know doesn't exist. 1. Load the page and observe an error page. This is good ??? 1. Open the record page for an existing record. Then hack the URL, changing the record id to something you know doesn't exist. 1. Load the page. 1. Expect to see an error page similar to the case with the schema not found. 1. Instead, observe that the record page loads a blank form with unsaved changes. This is bad because it's unclear to the user what happened. We should show a "Record Not Found" page instead.

issueDTO.title: Error when listing records if record summary template references a deleted column
issueDTO.description: ## Steps to reproduce 1. Begin with the following sample data: ```sql create table issue_4895 ( id int primary key generated always as identity, a text, b text, parent int ); insert into issue_4895 (a, b, parent) values ('foo', 'bar', NULL), ('baz', 'bat', 1); alter table issue_4895 add constraint issue_4895_parent_fkey foreign key (parent) references issue_4895 (id); ``` 1. Open the table page for `issue_4895`. 1. Select the "foo" FK cell, and configure the Linked Record Summary to display both `a` and `b` columns. Save. 1. Now delete column `b` from the table. 1. Expect the sheet to load, displaying "foo" as the record summary for the linked record. Because the "bar" value from column `b` is no longer available, it should be silently ignored. 1. Notice that when the sheet reloads, there is an error. Although this error is not shown to the user, you can see it in the network tab of your dev tools if you find the request to the `records.list` API: > UndefinedColumn: column base.........pg.dropped.3........ does not exist > LINE 15: || COALESCE(msar.format_data(base."........pg.dropped.3.... > ^ > QUERY: > WITH > count_cte AS ( SELECT count(1) AS count FROM public.issue_4895 ), > enriched_results_cte AS ( SELECT msar.format_data(id) AS "1", msar.format_data(a) AS "2", msar.format_data(parent) AS "4", NULL AS __mathesar_gid, NULL AS __mathesar_gcount FROM public.issue_4895 ORDER BY "1" ASC LIMIT '5??? jsonb_build_array() > ) > , > 'count', coalesce(max(count_cte.count), 0), > 'grouping', NULL > ) AS rj > FROM enriched_results_cte > LEFT JOIN groups_cte ON enriched_results_cte.__mathesar_gid = groups_cte.id > CROSS JOIN count_cte > ) > SELECT records_json_cte.rj || summaries_json_cte.sj > FROM records_json_cte, summaries_json_cte; > > CONTEXT: PL/pgSQL function msar.list_records_from_table(oid,integer,integer,jsonb,jsonb,jsonb,boolean,jsonb) line 31 at EXECUTE

issueDTO.title: Refactoring for Unit Test Access Controls
issueDTO.description:
Part of #12048

## Issue
After most of the Unit Test migration in #12048, there are a lot of inconsistencies in access control test methods. This is because we did not migrate the many convenient, abstracted, and commonly used access control test methods from `ui/webapi/BaseActionTest.java` to `sqlui/webapi/BaseActionTest.java`.

After merging #13254, all of the access control test methods in `BaseActionTest.java` have been migrated. Hence, this issue aims to refactor the unit test access controls to use these convenient test methods.

## Progress
The progress for this refactoring can be found [here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1IcB-viJMrIOknYoBYasBuRBK9qnwY0-doEK4_Eb24IA/edit?gid=0#gid=0). I (the author) will update it when completed PRs are merged proactively.

## Steps to Contribute

1. Choose test(s) to work on in the above Google Sheets link
2. Check that no on else have claimed the test cases to work on within the last 2 weeks, or that it has been completed by follow up PRs (but not updated in the sheets)
3. Comment on this issue to indicate that you'd like to contribute on the chosen test(s). Update your comment if you need more than 2 weeks so that other contributors don't overlap with your work.
4. Create a PR to refactor the unit test(s).
5. Submit the PR, with a link to this issue by starting the description with "Part of #13304". 
6. Tag me or any other active reviewers and wait for us to review (so that we can get a notification)

## Tips

- Understand the access control test methods in `sqlui/webapi/BaseActionTest.java`, follow the refactoring in #13254
- Most of the access control testing logic in the migrated unit tests under `sqlui/webapi` follows the old unit tests under `ui/webapi`, so you may wish to reference the old unit test for help

issueDTO.title: `bad-unpacking` error when unpacking a TypedDict that inherits another TypedDict
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the Bug

I have the following minimal reproducer:

```python
import typing_extensions as te


class InheritFromMe(te.TypedDict):
    foo: bool


class TestBadUnpackingError(InheritFromMe):
    bar: bool


unpack_this: InheritFromMe = {"foo": True}
test1: TestBadUnpackingError = {"bar": True, **unpack_this}
test2: TestBadUnpackingError = {"bar": True, "foo": True}

print(f"{ test1 = }")
print(f"{ test2 = }")
```

The output of the program is:

```bash
$ python test.py
test1 = {'bar': True, 'foo': True}
test2 = {'bar': True, 'foo': True}
```

They're functionally equivalent, as far as I can tell. However, `pyrefly` reports the first as a `bad-unpacking` error:

```bash
$ pyrefly check test.py
ERROR Unpacked `TypedDict[InheritFromMe]` is not assignable to `TypedDict[TestBadUnpackingError]` [bad-unpacking]
  --> /Users/macinburrito/GitLocal/Work/semaphore/test.py:13:48
   |
13 | test1: TestBadUnpackingError = {"bar": True, **unpack_this}
   |                                                ^^^^^^^^^^^
   |
 INFO 1 error
```

I think that this shouldn't be a `bad-unpacking` error, but perhaps I'm missing some nuance of the type system here?

### Sandbox Link

https://pyrefly.org/sandbox/?project=N4IgZglgNgpgziAXKOBDAdgEwEYHsAeAdAA4CeSIAxAAQDqMUAxrgLYzUAuunAFuwAqkATjDBRS1AMoYcBADS8IcakuqpqxVAHMYAHXQ0A7nxHVSuAK7VGGaoaEQOMBXB6pTM6rHfo1eCxycpMQQ6FoqvoIcPLjohPqUCdQAEjAeHtaWxLDUYDCoHBYiyrhgispoWHj4iEkAtNQA4jCBIqhQdRwQbEHE7Ix8jADWoeF5MDiow-XUAKpw7CIAbvlQAPocwTAAFACUnNyhcH2MgaF5QiKYvfAzMPh9DmzogYaOPLzsAJIAIgCiuXyhWKvAKdnYcAsxGIuCEgW2MEIWkIagCuGYLGyLWc1C0uE6%2BMwolCjggsQUMRWQgULUYuxmtAcTjUWGoQgskVI0VimSJ1EwEBEp3EETMliE1GwQlwhgWQn0%2Bm6MLhvVGa3uTnQcDJWrUyicCvQ%2BkYUFQcGUX3QJkcADFpSwALI7JyEAAqW0wPwgp12tV81ADYFwuEQkuDUENxtN5uorvgHAAQqhMLN0JphqM-pdYdtLdaOHbWE7ffoAwHsO5Q3hcBGjXWOemhhseEpQ3m0rb7U7qABeajAXTgYOD0Ou9kwAC%2B%2BiccA4AEZR-Gkym01MRmEs9KJX2ByAK-KkLHxwoAFQnhtr5tKKcveMAJkXs%2BXqcbmez2-7g-3I6PFhxg6DXAfzHP8b30YgHBebYwEHYBOHjOde2oKcQHpNNII4aDYPg2c7yQlC0P0ZZVg2LZthnec0OI9pSL6cj7zQkA5BAAJoDgEhyEQKg5i6KBHAkMAOVOHU4ENIkyiDIQWAKNZ0AsFhsDSbYagiDh9jqAA%2BahZyEP0yzZFoil8GCQAAOXkxTdP7fAUP0JiQDIEQxFIQguBYKAKBoQQnJFSpZHwTJ0EgLQigKHV4gMKQYHYHgOA4Yg4EQAB6JLHNEcRCFhLQkpgdAkswdE4CS5ggogEKhDC2IktyWE1CWVBoFQbAchK4LQq6HlcGIDqtQishuXQOoqW1Hk%2B0HABmQg5zvQc7InZipi6FYbWgGAKD86oOJACcgA

issueDTO.title: Responses max_logprobs
issueDTO.description:
### 🚀 Describe the new functionality needed

Logprobs are an important tool to help users understand token prediction outcomes. They are currently missing from llama stack responses.

### Requirements
- The Responses Create requests has a [top_logprobs](https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/responses) field, which gets translated or dropped based on the the inference provider.
- The response object contains [top_lobprobs](https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/responses/object#responses/object-top_logprobs) which is equal to the output value from the provider, or None.

### 💡 Why is this needed? What if we don't build it?

Users that have max_logprobs set will get bad request errors.

### Other thoughts

_No response_
comments: @iamemilio logprobs and top_logprobs are not consistently implemented. which inference providers do you need?

Yes, many of these fields in responses are not consistently implemented, and its perfectly acceptable in those cases drop the input and return either None or a sane zero value. I also do not want llama stack to waste effort doing work that LiteLLM already does: https://docs.litellm.ai/docs/completion/input.

The easy first choices would be vLLM and OpenAI, but ultimately we should shift the burden of support for these parameters to LiteLLM as much as possible. All llama stack needs to do is be able to handle them as inputs and return them as outputs when appropriate.

Hey @iamemilio , I would like to work on this, can you please brief me about this and files to look at?.

thank you.

/assign

@wothmag07 I think this comment here is generally where I would point you for this issue as well: https://github.com/llamastack/llama-stack/issues/3562#issuecomment-3347287153

Logprobs are returned by inference engines and providers to track the probability of logging each token. It is important that we return these to the end user so that they can debug the token output they got. In those links I posted in the thread above, you will see that the responses API call gets converted into a chat completions call in llama stack. Then that completions call will get routed through litellm, which ideally handles all the logprobs and conversions if necessary.

I would say that your primary goal with these changes is to pick a few providers, probably: vLLM, OpenAI, ollama. Then make sure that:
1. The Responses Response object returns logprobs for those requests
2. The logprobs returned make sense in the context of each provider ( as much as you can reasonably verify ) 

Thanks for picking this up, and @ me if you have any more questions!
@iamemilio Just wanna clarify, what I have to consider the param name to be "top_logprobs" similar to that of OpenAI docs or "max_logprobs" or "log_probs"

issueDTO.title: Logging outputs to stderr instead of stdout
issueDTO.description:
## Description
Logging outputs to `sys.stderr` instead of `sys.stdout`.

## Expectation

### Acceptable
All to `sys.stdout`. It makes a better default because output can be piped without redirection.
| Log level | Output |
| --- | --- |
| `logging.DEBUG` | `sys.stdout` |
| `logging.INFO` | `sys.stdout` |
| `logging.WARNING` | `sys.stdout` |
| `logging.ERROR` | `sys.stdout` |
| `logging.CRITICAL` | `sys.stdout` |

### Best
All to `sys.stdout` except error and critical to `sys.stderr`. Warning goes to `sys.stdout` because script execution should not stop on warnings.
| Log level | Output |
| --- | --- |
| `logging.DEBUG` | `sys.stdout` |
| `logging.INFO` | `sys.stdout` |
| `logging.WARNING` | `sys.stdout` |
| `logging.ERROR` | `sys.stderr` |
| `logging.CRITICAL` | `sys.stderr` |

## Environment
https://github.com/creativecommons/quantifying/blob/b0230184f3c7e1929b1970463ac90eb1cfb15d1b/Pipfile#L34

## Additional context
- Logging is configured in `scripts/shared.py`
- [logging ??? Logging facility for Python ??? Python 3.11 documentation](https://docs.python.org/3.11/library/logging.html)
  - [logging.config ??? Logging configuration ??? Python 3.11 documentation](https://docs.python.org/3.11/library/logging.config.html)
  - [logging.handlers ??? Logging handlers ??? Python 3.11 documentation](https://docs.python.org/3.11/library/logging.handlers.html)

## Resolution
<!-- Replace the [ ] with [x] to check the box. -->
- [ ] I would be interested in resolving this bug.

issueDTO.title: Conflicting declaration error with `__using_if_exists__` in libc++
issueDTO.description:
When trying to use libc++ with LLVM libc on a baremetal platform, we encountered an issue with the `__using_if_exists__` attribute which was introduced in https://reviews.llvm.org/D90188:

```
In file included from /llvm_libcxx/include/algorithm:1973:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
/llvm_libcxx/include/__algorithm/remove.h:28:1: error: declaration conflicts with target of using declaration already in scope                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
   28 | remove(_ForwardIterator __first, _ForwardIterator __last, const _Tp& __value) {                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
      | ^                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
/llvm_libcxx/include/cstdio:155:1: note: target of using declaration                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
  155 | using ::remove _LIBCPP_USING_IF_EXISTS;                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
      | ^                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
/llvm_libcxx/include/cstdio:155:9: note: using declaration                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
  155 | using ::remove _LIBCPP_USING_IF_EXISTS;                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
      |         ^                                 
```

This is because baremetal version of the `stdio.h` libc header doesn't include `remove` (since there's no filesystem support).

A more minimal example of this issue is:

```cpp
void foo();

namespace N {
  void bar();

  using ::foo __attribute__((__using_if_exists__));
  using ::bar __attribute__((__using_if_exists__));
}

void baz() {
  N::bar();
}
```

This results in the following error (you can also see it at https://godbolt.org/z/dTxqnc1oP):

```
<source>:7:11: error: target of using declaration conflicts with declaration already in scope
    7 |   using ::bar __attribute__((__using_if_exists__));
      |           ^
<source>:7:3: note: target of using declaration
    7 |   using ::bar __attribute__((__using_if_exists__));
      |   ^
<source>:4:8: note: conflicting declaration
    4 |   void bar();
      |        ^
1 error generated.
Compiler returned: 1
```

Normally, `remove` is declared in `stdio.h`, which corresponds to the `foo` case.

In our case, there's no `remove` symbol in `stdio.h` and as such there's no such symbol in the global namespace, but there's `remove` in the `std::` namespace introduced by `algorithm` corresponding to the `bar` case.

Is this an issue with the `__using_if_exists__` implementation or intended behavior?

This is related to issue https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/issues/84879.

CC @ldionne @zygoloid @AaronBallman @epilk
comments:
Thanks for filing this issue! I've come across this several times on various platforms and I believe this is a Clang bug in the way it implements the attribute. Basically the intent is that if there is no `::bar` declaration, the `using ::bar __attribute__((using_if_exists));` declaration shouldn't declare anything. But the way this is implemented in Clang IIRC is that we actually do create a special kind of declaration representing "no declaration at all". And then that conflicts with the existing declaration for `N::bar`.

Hi!

This issue may be a good introductory issue for people new to working on LLVM. If you would like to work on this issue, your first steps are:

1. Check that no other contributor is working on this issue. If someone is assigned to the issue or claimed to be working on it, ping the person. After one week without a response, the assignee may be changed.
1. Leave a comment indicating that you are working on the issue, or just create a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) after following the steps below. [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.
1. Fix the issue locally.
1. [Run the test suite](https://llvm.org/docs/TestingGuide.html#unit-and-regression-tests) locally. Remember that the subdirectories under `test/` create fine-grained testing targets, so you can e.g. use `make check-clang-ast` to only run Clang's AST tests.
1. Create a Git commit.
1. Run [`git clang-format HEAD~1`](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/ClangFormat.html#git-integration) to format your changes.
1. Open a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) to the [upstream repository](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project) on GitHub. Detailed instructions can be found [in GitHub's documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/proposing-changes-to-your-work-with-pull-requests/creating-a-pull-request). [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.

If you have any further questions about this issue, don't hesitate to ask via a comment in the thread below.


@llvm/issue-subscribers-good-first-issue

Author: Petr Hosek (petrhosek)

<details>
When trying to use libc++ with LLVM libc on a baremetal platform, we encountered an issue with the `__using_if_exists__` attribute which was introduced in https://reviews.llvm.org/D90188:

```
In file included from /llvm_libcxx/include/algorithm:1973:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
/llvm_libcxx/include/__algorithm/remove.h:28:1: error: declaration conflicts with target of using declaration already in scope                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
   28 | remove(_ForwardIterator __first, _ForwardIterator __last, const _Tp& __value) {                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
      | ^                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
/llvm_libcxx/include/cstdio:155:1: note: target of using declaration                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
  155 | using ::remove _LIBCPP_USING_IF_EXISTS;                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
      | ^                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
/llvm_libcxx/include/cstdio:155:9: note: using declaration                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
  155 | using ::remove _LIBCPP_USING_IF_EXISTS;                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
      |         ^                                 
```

This is because baremetal version of the `stdio.h` libc header doesn't include `remove` (since there's no filesystem support).

A more minimal example of this issue is:

```cpp
void foo();

namespace N {
  void bar();

  using ::foo __attribute__((__using_if_exists__));
  using ::bar __attribute__((__using_if_exists__));
}

void baz() {
  N::bar();
}
```

This results in the following error (you can also see it at https://godbolt.org/z/dTxqnc1oP):

```
<source>:7:11: error: target of using declaration conflicts with declaration already in scope
    7 |   using ::bar __attribute__((__using_if_exists__));
      |           ^
<source>:7:3: note: target of using declaration
    7 |   using ::bar __attribute__((__using_if_exists__));
      |   ^
<source>:4:8: note: conflicting declaration
    4 |   void bar();
      |        ^
1 error generated.
Compiler returned: 1
```

Normally, `remove` is declared in `stdio.h`, which corresponds to the `foo` case.

In our case, there's no `remove` symbol in `stdio.h` and as such there's no such symbol in the global namespace, but there's `remove` in the `std::` namespace introduced by `algorithm` corresponding to the `bar` case.

Is this an issue with the `__using_if_exists__` implementation or intended behavior?

This is related to issue https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/issues/84879.

CC @<!-- -->ldionne @<!-- -->zygoloid @<!-- -->AaronBallman @<!-- -->epilk 
</details>
I see what looks like another manifestation of it, but here a previous using-if-exists declaration seem to conflict with the regular declaration (that's when building libc++ against llvm-libc headers), which seems to be the inverse example to the one @petrhosek mentioned:

```
In file included from src/libcxxabi/src/cxa_demangle.cpp:17:
In file included from src/libcxxabi/src/demangle/ItaniumDemangle.h:20:
In file included from src/libcxxabi/src/demangle/StringViewExtras.h:20:
In file included from src/libcxx/include/string_view:235:
In file included from src/libcxx/include/__string/char_traits.h:29:
src/libcxx/include/cstdio:120:9: error: target of using declaration conflicts with declaration already in scope
  120 | using ::FILE _LIBCPP_USING_IF_EXISTS;
      |         ^
libc/include/llvm-libc-macros/../llvm-libc-types/FILE.h:12:21: note: target of using declaration
   12 | typedef struct FILE FILE;
      |                     ^
src/libcxx/include/cwchar:137:1: note: conflicting declaration
  137 | using ::FILE _LIBCPP_USING_IF_EXISTS;
      | ^
1 error generated.
```

summary.main: When trying to use libc++ with LLVM libc on a baremetal platform, we encountered an issue with the `__using_if_exists__` attribute which was introduced in https://reviews.llvm.org/D90188. The issue is caused by a conflict between the `__using_if_exists__` attribute and a declaration already in scope.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue is related to the `__using_if_exists__` attribute implementation or intended behavior, and the issue is to determine whether this is an issue with the implementation or intended behavior.
summary.attemptedFixes: There are no specific attempted fixes mentioned in the issue, but it is suggested that the issue may be related to the way Clang implements the `__using_if_exists__` attribute.
summary.otherNotes: This is an issue with the `__using_if_exists__` attribute implementation or intended behavior. It seems that the `__using_if_exists__` attribute is trying to use a declaration that is already in scope, which is causing a conflict. The issue is related to issue #84879. There are two examples provided: one where `remove` is declared in `stdio.h` and another where `remove` is declared in `std::` namespace. The issue may be a good introductory issue for people new to working on LLVM.

issueDTO.title: Units larger than `h` in `GrafanaAlertRuleGroup#.spec.rules[*].for` are rejected on apply
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**
When exporting Alerts and AlertGroups from Grafana in order to populate a `GrafanaAlertRuleGroup` CR, we see that when specific values are picked for pending period( `.spec.rules[*].for`) like `24h`, Grafana will export it as `1d`.
At the time of writing, years, weeks, and days are not supported in the `.spec.rules[*].for` field.

**Version**
v5.19.4

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Open a Grafana `v11.5.3` or later
2. Create or modify an alert rule
3. Set the pending period to `24h`
4. Save and Export the alert, notice it should have converted the pending period to `1d`
5. Apply the rule as a CRD
6. ```
    # grafanaalertrulegroups.grafana.integreatly.org "grafana-health" was not valid:
    # * spec.rules[0].for: Invalid value: "1d": spec.rules[0].for in body should match '^([0-9]+(\.[0-9]+)?(ns|us|??s|ms|s|m|h))+$'
    ```

**Expected behavior**
Following the above steps, the CRD should be succesfully applied and synchronized with matching instances.

**Suspect component/Location where the bug might be occurring**
https://github.com/grafana/grafana-operator/blob/44b51c8f2643ab00a76d609858419dbbe0ba422a/api/v1beta1/grafanaalertrulegroup_types.go#L52

**Runtime (please complete the following information):**

- OS: Linux
- Grafana Operator Version: v5.19.4
- Environment: Kubernetes 1.31
- Deployment type: Helm
- Other: N/A

**Additional context**
It might be worth it to remove `ns, us, ??s, ms` as they do not make much sense as alert delays and add `d` and `w`. and omit `y` as that does not make much sense either.
comments:
@Baarsgaard I'd like to contribute here. 

Please assign to me

So we need to update the crds to accept the new units "d" and "w" and update the codes to handle them right?
Are we removing ns, us, ??s, ms ?

Indeed!
Adding a test using the `d` and `w` values is a bit important as the default `time.Duration` struct in Go cannot parse the units.
Hence there needs to be custom parsing of it to derive the number of seconds that is sent to Grafana:
https://github.com/grafana/grafana-operator/blob/1bb15b577957bc893344037626db242b1a96c68c/controllers/alertrulegroup_controller.go#L215

Grafana itself might have some code we can use for handling this?

@Baarsgaard I was just updating the crds and making dev setup. From what i see, we dont handle "d" and "w" in current repo code. 

I need help in the following

we ok introducing this grafana package to handle times?
https://github.com/grafana/grafana-plugin-sdk-go/tree/main/backend/gtime

Or I could introduce an extended duration parsing helpers to handle them.

Letme know

@vignesh-codes is the `grafana-plugin-sdk-go` the only place you found this logic? I'd expect it to be part of `grafana/grafana` as well but I haven't checked myself yet.

If it's in `grafana/grafana` as well, I'd prefer that version. Otherwise, we're good with importing the package

repository.description: An operator for Grafana that installs and manages Grafana instances, Dashboards and Datasources through Kubernetes/OpenShift CRs
repository.name: grafana-operator

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to resolve the bug where Grafana exports `24h` as `1d` and rejects it on apply, and to update the Grafana Alert Rule Group CRD to support units `d` and `w` in the `.spec.rules[*].for` field.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The validation or requirement is that the `.spec.rules[*].for` field should match a specific pattern, which is not supported for units larger than `h`. The requirement is to update the CRDs to accept the new units `d` and `w` and update the code to handle them correctly.
summary.attemptedFixes: The discussion mentions introducing the `grafana-plugin-sdk-go` package to handle times or extending the duration parsing helpers to handle `d` and `w` units. There is also a mention of using the `gtime` package from the Grafana repository.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to the Grafana Alert Rule Group CRD, specifically the `.spec.rules[*].for` field, which rejects units larger than `h` and does not support years, weeks, and days. The expected behavior is for the CRD to be successfully applied and synchronized with matching instances. The suspect component is the Grafana Operator, specifically the `grafanaalertrulegroup_types.go` file.

issueDTO.title: `--eval-file` requires `=`, impossible to provide from `#!`
issueDTO.description:
Version: Deno 2.5.3
CC: @najumancheril, @bartlomieju, @dsherret 
Related: #23071

Hi folks. I'm trying to run a REPL from a script with least steps and moving parts. The distinction made in #23071 (to only get the `export`s) is not decisive to my use case, so `--eval-file` is fine too. However, the `--eval-file` flag as merged in #14247 doesn't seem to work in hashbang context:

```sh
#!/usr/bin/env -S deno repl --allow-read --eval-file
console.log('hello from data.ts')
```

```
error: equal sign is needed when assigning values to '--eval-file=<eval-file>...'
```

Were it not for the equal sign requirement, this would parse as `deno repl --allow-read --eval-file data.ts` and drop me right where I need to be. The equal sign is explained to be needed for passing multiple values (`--eval-file=1.ts,2.ts`).

Do you guys see a way to make this work with multiple flag instances (`--eval-file 1.ts --eval-file 2.ts`), making the equal sign optional, without breaking backwards compatibility?
comments:
I'm a bit unsure what workflow you're trying to create. Here is my attempt to replicate what you are doing. Here is my `data.ts`:

```console.log("hello from data.ts")```

Here is my shell script (`test.sh`):

```#!/usr/bin/env -S deno repl --allow-read --eval-file=data.ts```

When I run this script, I see this error message:

```
$ ./test.sh
error: unexpected argument './test.sh' found

Usage: deno repl [OPTIONS] [-- [ARGS]...]
```

This is happening because ./test.sh is being passed as a command-line argument to deno. I can stop deno from trying to process this argument by adding -- to the end of my script contents. Here is my modified `test.sh`:

```
#!/usr/bin/env -S deno repl --allow-read --eval-file=data.ts --
```

I now see the following:

```
$ ./test.sh
hello from data.ts
Deno 2.5.0
exit using ctrl+d, ctrl+c, or close()
>
```

Does this address your concern?
I think it would be ok to get rid of the `=` requirement.
I'm interested in working on this issue. Could you provide more context about what you're looking for? Any additional details about requirements or constraints would be helpful.

summary.main: Make the --eval-file flag optional, without breaking backwards compatibility, and make it possible to use multiple flag instances.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The flag --eval-file requires an equal sign (=) which is not present in the hashbang context, and it's not possible to use multiple flag instances without the equal sign.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author tried to replicate the issue and found that adding -- to the end of the script contents can stop deno from trying to process the script as a command-line argument.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about making the --eval-file flag optional, without breaking backwards compatibility, and making it possible to use multiple flag instances. The current issue is that the flag requires an equal sign (=) which is not present in the hashbang context. The author is trying to run a REPL from a script with least steps and moving parts.

issueDTO.title: Add engines property to root package.json
issueDTO.description:
<!-- ???????????? Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ???????????? -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

The [How to Contribute][1] guide mentions that we're supposed to do `npm install` but doesn't mention which npm version is supposed to be used.

It'd be great if the [engines][2] property is added to the root package.json for quick reference of the node and npm versions that are supposed to be used. As an added benefit, it'd also throw an error if an unsupported version is used.

[1]: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#build
[2]: https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v11/configuring-npm/package-json#engines
comments:
We already have a check on the node version in https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/dadbc584d9b02c5964621c67eebefa871c051655/build/npm/preinstall.js#L12-L15. We don't have an explicit check on npm version but the implicit is that use the one that is shipped with node. Adding a check for npm version can be added to this same file, PR welcome.

I am not keen on adding an engine property, it just increases the places we have to keep updated when bumping runtime versions. Lets reuse the checks we have today. Thanks!

Shouldn't there be an upper bound on the node version as well? The current check only checks for a minimum version required. This would result in unpredictable behaviour if node tomorrow releases a new major version not compatible with the codebase. 🤔 

There already are multiple places the version is maintained at, looks like [.nvmrc](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/.nvmrc) is the primary source used by the GitHub workflows.

> it just increases the places we have to keep updated

Quite opposite, it *decreases* the places to keep updated. All the isolated places where the version is maintained can be unified to have a single source of truth for the node version.

The engines field can be used by both [workflows](https://github.com/actions/setup-node/blob/main/docs/advanced-usage.md#node-version-file) and code: `import { engines } from "../../package.json"`.

Thanks for working on this!
I???d like to get involved???are there any guidelines or examples for contributing to this part of the codebase?
I???ve read the ???How to Contribute??? guide, but if you have any tips specific to editing the engines field or best practices for aligning version management (as discussed above), I???d love to learn more

Hello, I???d love to help with this issue. I???ve reviewed the _How to Contribute_ guide and set up the local development environment successfully. I've also read through the comments here and can try to pick up where things have been left off.

I saw that the team is not currently planning to add an engines field due to the added maintenance burden, but a PR is welcome to add an explicit check on npm version in build/npm/preinstall.js. I???d be happy to submit a PR that adds this check while following the structure of the existing Node version validation (in reference to the last comments here by deepak & cseas).

I noticed there's already an open PR (#255060) aiming to address this, but it appears to be stalled or potentially not moving forward based on the recent 👎 reaction. If that PR ends up not being accepted, I???d be happy to submit an alternative implementation that adds the requested npm version check to build/npm/preinstall.js, following the structure of the existing Node version validation.

Could I be assigned to this issue?

issueDTO.title: Review AsyncIterableObject usage: potential memory leaks and migration to AsyncIterableProducer
issueDTO.description:
# GitHub Issue: Review AsyncIterableObject usage: potential memory leaks and migration to AsyncIterableProducer

**Title:** Review AsyncIterableObject usage: potential memory leaks and migration to AsyncIterableProducer

## Problem

`AsyncIterableObject` has a potential memory leak issue when iterables are only consumed once. The class stores all emitted values in an internal `_results` array to support multiple iterations, but this means values are never garbage collected in long-running iterations even when the iterable is only consumed once.

`AsyncIterableProducer` was introduced as an alternative that doesn't store values, making it more memory-efficient for single-consumption scenarios. However, this means that a second iteration will miss initial values.

## Analysis

We found **112 occurrences** of `AsyncIterableObject` across the codebase that should be reviewed to determine if they can be migrated to `AsyncIterableProducer` for better memory efficiency.

## Action Items

Please review the usages you've contributed to and determine if they can be migrated to `AsyncIterableProducer`:

### Contributors to Review

- [ ] **@alexdima** (31 occurrences) - Core async.ts implementation and editor hover functionality
- [ ] **@jrieken** (18 occurrences) - AsyncIterableSource, tests, chat and language model features
- [x] **@aiday-mar** (15 occurrences) - Editor hover functionality (inlay hints, color picker, markdown hover)
- [x] **@amunger** (19 occurrences total) - Notebook-related functionality and tests
- [x] **@hediet** (8 occurrences) - Core async functionality and inline completions
- [x] **@Tyriar** (5 occurrences) - Terminal shell integration
- [ ] **@sandy081** (4 occurrences) - Extension services
- [ ] **@joaomoreno** (2 occurrences) - Workspace functionality
- [x] **@connor4312** (2 occurrences) - MCP (Model Context Protocol) server
- [ ] **@aeschli** (2 occurrences) - Chat code block operations
- [ ] **@DonJayamanne** (1 occurrence) - Chat code block operations
- [x] **@mjbvz** (1 occurrence) - Editor hover functionality

### Review Criteria

For each usage, consider:

1. **Single vs Multiple Consumption**: Is the AsyncIterable consumed only once or multiple times?
2. **Memory Sensitivity**: Are large amounts of data being emitted that should be garbage collected promptly?
3. **Performance Impact**: Would switching to AsyncIterableProducer provide meaningful memory savings?

### Migration Guidelines

??? **Good candidates for AsyncIterableProducer:**
- Single-use iterables (consumed once then discarded)
- Large data streams
- Real-time data processing
- Event streams

??? **Keep AsyncIterableObject for:**
- Iterables that need to be consumed multiple times
- Cases where re-iteration is expected

## Files to Review

<details>
<summary>Core Implementation (31 occurrences)</summary>

**src/vs/base/common/async.ts**
- Lines: 1963, 1975, 1977, 1978, 1983, 1984, 1989, 1990, 1995, 1996, 2005, 2063, 2064, 2071, 2072, 2075, 2076, 2085, 2086, 2087, 2088, 2091, 2092, 2095, 2096, 2108, 2171, 2184, 2188, 2215, 2228, 2267, 2375

</details>

<details>
<summary>Editor Features (38 occurrences)</summary>

**Hover functionality:**
- src/vs/editor/contrib/hover/browser/contentHoverComputer.ts (5 occurrences)
- src/vs/editor/contrib/hover/browser/markdownHoverParticipant.ts (5 occurrences)
- src/vs/editor/contrib/hover/browser/getHover.ts (3 occurrences)
- src/vs/editor/contrib/hover/browser/hoverOperation.ts (3 occurrences)
- src/vs/editor/contrib/hover/browser/hoverTypes.ts (2 occurrences)

**Inlay hints:**
- src/vs/editor/contrib/inlayHints/browser/inlayHintsHover.ts (7 occurrences)

**Other editor features:**
- src/vs/editor/contrib/inlineCompletions/browser/model/provideInlineCompletions.ts (3 occurrences)
- src/vs/editor/contrib/colorPicker/browser/hoverColorPicker/hoverColorPickerParticipant.ts (3 occurrences)

</details>

<details>
<summary>Workbench Features (24 occurrences)</summary>

**Notebook functionality:**
- src/vs/workbench/contrib/notebook/test/browser/ (15 occurrences across test files)
- src/vs/workbench/contrib/notebook/common/notebookKernelService.ts (2 occurrences)
- src/vs/workbench/api/browser/mainThreadNotebookKernels.ts (3 occurrences)

**Chat functionality:**
- src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/actions/chatCodeblockActions.ts (2 occurrences)
- src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/actions/codeBlockOperations.ts (2 occurrences)

</details>

<details>
<summary>Extension and API Features (19 occurrences)</summary>

- src/vs/workbench/services/extensions/browser/extensionService.ts (2 occurrences)
- src/vs/workbench/services/extensions/electron-browser/nativeExtensionService.ts (2 occurrences)
- src/vs/workbench/api/common/extHostTerminalShellIntegration.ts (4 occurrences)
- src/vs/workbench/api/common/extHostLanguageModels.ts (2 occurrences)
- src/vs/workbench/api/common/extHostWorkspace.ts (2 occurrences)
- src/vs/workbench/contrib/mcp/common/mcpServer.ts (2 occurrences)

</details>

## Next Steps

1. Each contributor should review their assigned usages
2. Create follow-up PRs for migrations where appropriate
3. Update documentation/guidelines for when to use each class
4. Consider adding ESLint rules to guide future usage

This review will help improve VS Code's memory efficiency and prevent potential memory leaks in async iteration scenarios.

---

issueDTO.title: [Feature request]: Ensure Help Documentation is Updated and Accurate for All Tutorial Steps
issueDTO.description:
### Problem: What is happening?

Devopness provides a tutorial that guides users through key workflows, such as adding projects, environments, servers, applications, and more. The tutorial is available in the [Devopness Guide][1]. To support users during these workflows, help documentation is displayed via the `?` buttons on various pages.

However, several challenges have been identified:
1. **Missing Documentation**: Some pages accessed during the tutorial do not have associated help documentation, leaving users without guidance when they need it most.
2. **Incorrect Documentation Paths**: Certain help articles exist but are not properly linked, making them inaccessible via the `?` button.
3. **Outdated Instructions**: Some help documentation reflects older UI/UX flows that have since been updated, causing confusion for users who rely on these instructions.

This issue aims to address these challenges by ensuring all tutorial steps and key pages have complete, accurate, and actionable help documentation. By doing so, we can enhance the onboarding experience, provide clarity, and ensure users can complete workflows efficiently.

---

### **Task List**

#### Missing Documentation
- [x] #1203
- [x] #1206
- [x] #1207
- [ ] #1208
- [x] #1209
- [x] #1210
- [ ] #1211
- [ ] #1212
- [ ] #1213
- [ ] #1214
- [x] #1215
- [x] #1216
- [x] #1217
- [x] #1204
- [ ] #1205


---

#### Path Fixes
- [ ] #1218
- [x] #1219

---

#### Improvements to Existing Documentation
- [x] #1220
- [x] #1221
- [x] #1223

[1]: https://devopness.com/docs


### Expected behavior

All tutorial steps and key pages should have complete, accurate, and actionable help documentation accessible via the `?` buttons. Users should be able to follow workflows without confusion or interruption.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Go to the [Devopness tutorial](https://devopness.com/docs).
2. Navigate through the tutorial steps (e.g., projects, environments, servers).
3. Click on the ? button for help documentation on pages listed in the issue (e.g., projects/list-projects, teams/list-teams).
4. Observe whether the expected help documentation is available or accessible.

### Which Devopness module(s) are the source of the bug?

Documentation

### Package Version

_No response_

### Reproduction link

_No response_

### Additional details

_No response_

issueDTO.title: Add Cypress Tests for Suggestion Submission Flow
issueDTO.description:
## Description
End-to-end tests confirming user can open form, fill it, and submit successfully.

**NOTE:** If working on this before #648 and #649 are completed, it is acceptable that the test will not pass. It will still help us do quick validation once they are completed by targeting the newly created resources.

1. Add a Cypress test that performs the following actions in `cypress/e2e/desktop/suggestion.cy.js`
   1. Clicks on any tap on the page
   1. Clicks on the "Edit" button on the modal that appears
   3. Fills out the form, making sure to fill out all pages of the form (See: https://github.com/phlask/phlask-map/blob/develop/cypress/e2e/desktop/crowdsourcing.cy.js for a reference implementation of that)
   4. Does NOT click the "Submit" button (to avoid adding junk data to our database)
5. If necessary, add `data-cy` attributes to resources in order to allow Cypress to target them for clicking/writing/etc.
   - For an example of how to target elements, see the the `should successfully submit a water site for testing` test in the `cypress/e2e/desktop/crowdsourcing.cy.js` file.
   - For an example of how components are updated to support the example above, see line 27 of the `src/components/AddResourceModal/ChooseResource.jsx` file.
6. When opening a Pull Request for this story, make sure to include a video recording of the completed test to help reviewers.
   - When you run tests locally, a video of the test should automatically be recorded in the `cypress/videos` folder.

## Complexity
~100 LOC test file; integration + mock API
comments: In thinking about this more, we could implement this as a test that expects the form to be working based on the design to be defined in this ticket.

issueDTO.title: Error when previewing record summary if selected cell is null
issueDTO.description: The Linked Record Summary configuration utilizes the active cell to find a sample record when rendering a record summary preview. But if the active cell is `NULL`, then we end up with this behavior. > An unknown error occurred. This error message might be confusing to the user. It might give them the impression that something is wrong or broken. In this case I think it would be better to hide the entire preview fieldset.

issueDTO.title: [Bug] Various packages stopped updating due to checkver errors
issueDTO.description:
### Description
The issue comes from:
- #16349

There are lots of error logs during excavator execution. Various packages stopped updating due to checkver errors.
See: https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Extras/actions/runs/18627830520/job/53108310389

Contributors are warmly welcome to help fix one or more of these broken manifest. Please note:
- Make sure there are no existing fix PRs.
- Create a separate PR or a separate commit for each manifest, with a title following the naming rules.
- Please do not attempt to close this issue in your PR.
- For manifests that are still available but will no longer receive updates, remove their checkver fields instead of deprecating them.
- For autoupdate filed, if we can still install a specific version via `scoop install app@version` (i.e., autoupdate is version-specific), removing it is also not recommended.

comments:
> ... because the default broadcasting behavior of enzyme batch is enough.

Do you mean unrolling or leave the op unchanged?

The batch pass will take the original op:

```mlir
%0 = stablehlo.add %arg0, %arg1 : tensor<10xf32>
```

and just prepend the broadcasted dimensions (_e.g._ 20x4):

```mlir
%0 = stablehlo.add %arg0, %arg1 : tensor<20x4x10xf32>
```

This is the default behavior for all ops unless they implement `BatchOpInterface`.
whileop definitely shouldn't be unrolled here in most cases [since it almost always has a number of iterations fixed by a constant aka non data-dependent value]
Should `CustomCallOp` always fallback to the looped version?
tenatively I think so, it at minimum feels like a better default [more likely to not error]

summary.main: The main goal of this issue is to discuss the implementation of BatchOpInterface for ops and the default broadcasting behavior of Enzyme batch.
summary.validationOrRequirement: Ops that implement BatchOpInterface should follow the default broadcasting behavior of Enzyme batch.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue discusses the default broadcasting behavior of Enzyme batch and the implementation of BatchOpInterface for ops. It also touches on the unrolling of ops like WhileOp and CustomCallOp.
summary.otherNotes: The default broadcasting behavior of Enzyme batch is enough, and ops that don't implement BatchOpInterface will be left unchanged. CustomCallOp should always fallback to the looped version, and WhileOp should not be unrolled in most cases.

issueDTO.title: [Docs]: Clarify support for consuming SWC in various UI frameworks
issueDTO.description: Are there also plans for adding support for other frameworks besides react?
comments:
As per https://custom-elements-everywhere.com/#vue Vue doesn't need the help that [React does](https://custom-elements-everywhere.com/#react) when working with the DOM. What would you see as the benefits of a wrapper in the Vue context? I know we already have users that leverage Vue and then SWC directly as DOM, but we've not collected any feedback about additional work to support this context.
That's really cool supporting al off the front end frameworks out of the box without the need of a special wrapper🚀

Perhaps an idea to also mention this to the main website to make this more clear.

Does this mean that the getting started and all the examples are applicable to all front end frameworks as well?

At least react seems to require a special wrapper
![image](https://github.com/adobe/spectrum-web-components/assets/25219229/de05b3f1-d908-4481-b545-357d7d57c998)
The custom elements should be usable in all front end frameworks, yet. This is one of the key features of working with web components APIs!

Even in React you don't _need_ a wrapper, but because of the ergonomics of their virtual DOM the amount of work you might end up doing to complete even a simple DOM element interaction can turn people off from working with our elements in that context. Hence the wrapper.

We make this statement on the home page:
```
Framework agnostic [#](https://opensource.adobe.com/spectrum-web-components/index.html#framework-agnostic)

You can use web components with any framework, since they???re supported and encapsulated at the browser level.
```
But, we'd love to hear if there was a better wording or location to include such information.

Beyond that, we'll close this issue by the start of next week, and if you run into more focused questions/requests during your adoption, we'd love to see new issues for those discussion. Thanks in advance!
Never heard of web components, but it sounds interesting.

Perhaps you can consider adding something like this to docs. It will also help for SEO

## Current support

| Front-end framework | Status         | Note                                  |
|:---------------------|:----------------|:---------------------------------------|
| React               | ?????? Active   | Requires using `swc-react` |
| Angular             | :white_check_mark: Active   |  |
| Vue.js              | :white_check_mark: Active   |  |
| Bootstrap           | :white_check_mark: Active   |  |
| Svelte              | :white_check_mark: Active   |  |
| Ember.js            | :white_check_mark: Active   |   |
| Backbone.js         | :x: Inactive    |  Not supported  |
| jQuery              | :x: Inactive    |  Not supported |

https://custom-elements-everywhere.com

issueDTO.title: Google Sheet App Script
issueDTO.description:
i have succ set-up 

Webhook via google sheet app as per guid available in site but one issue with this

One msg come multiple time like 10/ to 15 time in just 20 msg google sheet use 2000 plus row so please share the app script code 

To solve this issue
comments:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/dacd1433-85d6-44bc-b41b-7091db5e0c47)
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a98feddb-660f-4c2f-8193-950213982489)
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f3d8f948-7763-4733-8160-ef2154639937)

Hello!

Thank you for your interest in the project!

It appears your script isn't returning a success code within a reasonable time. In this case, the application is making multiple attempts to send the webhook. For more information on retries, see https://docs.sms-gate.app/features/webhooks/#step-5-receive-the-payload.

Make sure the request to the script returns a `2xx` HTTP status code and the request processing time doesn't exceed 30 seconds. Try making the request manually using curl.

Also, check the application logs according to the documentation: https://docs.sms-gate.app/features/logging/#accessing-logs

If nothing helps, please provide the curl results, as well as the application logs retrieved through the local server API.

I am don't know how to use curl

I have attached app snapshot logs



*D-X Game Zone*
*Nizam Kumbhar*
*Mo.9879123217*

> Make sure the request to the script returns a 2xx HTTP status code and
> the request processing time doesn't exceed 30 seconds. Try making the
> request manually using curl.
>
> Also, check the application logs according to the documentation:
> https://docs.sms-gate.app/features/logging/#accessing-logs
>
> If nothing helps, please provide the curl results, as well as the
> application logs retrieved through the local server API.
>
> ???
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/capcom6/android-sms-gateway/issues/285#issuecomment-3424941412>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ACPPCYCKDFE4LGSJ5HFLKK33YXIQPAVCNFSM6AAAAACJXUKPROVHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV43OSLTON2WKQ3PNVWWK3TUHMZTIMRUHE2DCNBRGI>
> .
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>

Sorry, but I don't see any app logs in your message.

However, I did find that Google Apps Script returns a `302` status code for the `POST` request. This is why the application is retrying.

A quick fix is ??????to disable retry attempts in the application settings: **Settings** -> **Webhooks** -> **Retry count** -> 1.

I'll look into this further.

I've identified the root cause of the issue.

The Google Apps Script (GAS) is responding to the POST request with an HTTP `302` redirect. According to HTTP standards, POST requests are not automatically followed for redirects because it can lead to unintended side-effects (like duplicate submissions).

Even if we were to ignore this standard, the subsequent redirected request would remain a POST method. The GAS endpoint likely expects a GET request at the redirect location, which would result in a `405 Method Not Allowed` error. Therefore, the webhook delivery would fail regardless.

Since this behavior is specific to how Google Apps Script handles requests, I don't have plans to adjust the application's core HTTP client to accommodate it at this time. The most effective solution is to set the "Retry count" to `1` in your application settings to prevent multiple attempts.

Another option is to implement deduplication in your Google Apps Script code. Each webhook payload includes a unique event ID. You can check your sheet to see if an event with that ID has already been processed before inserting a new row. This would make your webhook handler idempotent and resilient to any duplicate delivery attempts.

issueDTO.title: [DocDB] Metric rocksdb_bytes_read doesn't seem to be updated even on read workloads
issueDTO.description:
Jira Link: [DB-16467](https://yugabyte.atlassian.net/browse/DB-16467)
### Description

`rocksdb_bytes_read` metric is not updated on read workloads. It would be good to get it to work, since its counterpart - `rocksdb_bytes_written` is being updated for write workloads.

For example, [Graphana query](https://portal.dev.yugabyte.com:9090/query?g0.expr=rocksdb_bytes_read&g0.show_tree=0&g0.tab=table&g0.end_input=2025-04-24+22%3A38%3A30&g0.moment_input=2025-04-24+22%3A38%3A30&g0.range_input=1h&g0.res_type=custom&g0.res_step=30&g0.display_mode=lines&g0.show_exemplars=0) for internal test universes show 0 value for `rocksdb_bytes_read`.

### Issue Type

kind/bug

### Warning: Please confirm that this issue does not contain any sensitive information

- [x] I confirm this issue does not contain any sensitive information.

[DB-16467]: https://yugabyte.atlassian.net/browse/DB-16467?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiNWRkNTljNzYxNjVmNDY3MDlhMDU5Y2ZhYzA5YTRkZjUiLCJwIjoiZ2l0aHViLWNvbS1KU1cifQ
comments:
Hey, I would like to suggest/implement a fix.

I already looked into the code and probably found where it is located, but a question came up. Does the same happen for the 'rocksdb_number_multiget_bytes_read' metric?
If so I would be looking into fixing both issues.

Thank you in advance!
@nichideropa , Yes please send out the PR and we will take a look. cc @es1024  to help with the review.

@rthallamko3 @es1024 Hi 👋🏻 I was also curious about this metrics behaviour and did a bit of research. I'm new to YugabyteDB source code, but here is my understanding so far...

**TL;DR**: - `rocksdb_bytes_read` consistently returns 0 because **YugabyteDB's DocDB layer uses [RocksDB iterators](https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/wiki/Iterator) for all read operations**, not direct `rocksdb::DB::Get()` calls. Instead, it exclusively uses `rocksdb::DB::NewIterator()` through the `BoundedRocksDbIterator` wrapper. This means:

- **`BYTES_READ`** counter (tracked by `rocksdb_bytes_read`) is never incremented
    - This is never incremented in **[db_impl.cc:4388](https://github.com/yugabyte/yugabyte-db/blob/master/src/yb/rocksdb/db/db_impl.cc#L4388)** in YugabyteDB
- **`ITER_BYTES_READ`** counter (tracked by `rocksdb_db_iter_bytes_read`) shows actual read activity
    - This is incremented in **[db_iter.cc:147,370](https://github.com/yugabyte/yugabyte-db/blob/master/src/yb/rocksdb/db/db_iter.cc#L147)**

## How I've read the code path

As far as I understand, the RocksDB metrics end up being exposed as DocDB/PostgreSQL "statistics" in the following relationships:

```
YSQL Query ??? PgGate ??? DocDB ??? RocksDB
                  ???
      PostgreSQL Metrics ??? Mapping ??? RocksDB Statistics
                  ???
           Prometheus Metrics
```

Current mapping in **[docdb_statistics.cc:57-64](https://github.com/yugabyte/yugabyte-db/blob/master/src/yb/docdb/docdb_statistics.cc#L57-L64)**:

```cpp
{pggate::YB_STORAGE_GAUGE_REGULARDB_BYTES_READ, rocksdb::BYTES_READ}
//...
{pggate::YB_STORAGE_GAUGE_REGULARDB_ITER_BYTES_READ, rocksdb::ITER_BYTES_READ},
```

YugabyteDB's read path:

1. **[docdb_rocksdb_util.cc:318](https://github.com/yugabyte/yugabyte-db/blob/master/src/yb/docdb/docdb_rocksdb_util.cc#L318)** - creates iterator
2. **[bounded_rocksdb_iterator.cc:25](https://github.com/yugabyte/yugabyte-db/blob/master/src/yb/docdb/bounded_rocksdb_iterator.cc#L25)** - Calls `rocksdb->NewIterator(read_opts)` (instead of `rocksdb->Get()`)
3. **[bounded_rocksdb_iterator.cc:32,35,58](https://github.com/yugabyte/yugabyte-db/blob/master/src/yb/docdb/bounded_rocksdb_iterator.cc#L32)** - See - uses iterator methods (`Seek()`, `Next()`, etc.)

As far as I read the source code, **I cannot find any other DocDB layer using `rocksdb->Get` to read data.**

## Minimal Reproduction

I've tested it at 3fa5a66374c2ec2fd572aed8d297297ce98f3214 (the latest commit from the master branch when I've forked)

```bash
# Start local cluster
./bin/yugabyted start

# Create test table and insert data
./bin/ysqlsh -h 127.0.0.1 -p 5433 -c "
CREATE TABLE users (id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, age INTEGER);
INSERT INTO users (name, age) VALUES ('Alice', 30), ('Bob', 25), ('Charlie', 35);
"

# Perform read operations
./bin/ysqlsh -h 127.0.0.1 -p 5433 -c "SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = 1;"
./bin/ysqlsh -h 127.0.0.1 -p 5433 -c "SELECT * FROM users;"
```

And then I've check two metrics

```sh
curl -s 'http://127.0.0.1:9000/prometheus-metrics' | grep rocksdb_bytes_read | grep users
curl -s 'http://127.0.0.1:9000/prometheus-metrics' | grep rocksdb_db_iter_bytes_read | grep users
```

`rocksdb_bytes_read` returns 0

    rocksdb_bytes_read{table_id="000034d400003000800000000000400b",table_name="users",table_type="PGSQL_TABLE_TYPE",namespace_name="yugabyte",metric_type="tablet",exported_instance="<redacted>"} 0 1758805447912

`rocksdb_db_iter_bytes_read` returns value (and this value keeps incrementing every time after I run `SELECT`)

    rocksdb_db_iter_bytes_read{table_id="000034d400003000800000000000400b",table_name="users",table_type="PGSQL_TABLE_TYPE",namespace_name="yugabyte",metric_type="tablet",exported_instance="<redacted">"} 313 1758805631154


This can be confirmed by the following query:

```sh
$ ./bin/ysqlsh -c "EXPLAIN (ANALYZE, DIST, DEBUG) SELECT * FROM users;" | head -n 15
                                              QUERY PLAN
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 Seq Scan on users  (cost=0.00..100.00 rows=1000 width=528) (actual time=0.204..0.205 rows=3 loops=1)
   Storage Table Read Requests: 1
   Storage Table Read Execution Time: 0.188 ms
   Storage Table Read Ops: 1
   Storage Table Rows Scanned: 3
     Metric rocksdb_number_db_seek: 1.000
     Metric rocksdb_number_db_next: 3.000
     Metric rocksdb_number_db_seek_found: 1.000
     Metric rocksdb_number_db_next_found: 2.000
     Metric rocksdb_iter_bytes_read: 191.000 <-------------------- NOT rocksdb_bytes_read
     Metric docdb_keys_found: 3.000
     Metric ql_read_latency: sum: 21.000, count: 1.000
 Planning Time: 8.112 ms
```

## Proposed Fix

If my unrederstanding is correct, I'd say this is rather a metrics naming issue not implementation bug - you'd need a documentation or blog article explaining which RocksDB metrics user would really want to track.

WDYT?

Thanks for the insight @kenju , we are brainstorming internally. Current thinking is to fold the accounting for  `rocksdb_iter_bytes_read` into `rocksdb_bytes_read`, so as to be consistent with `rocksdb_bytes_written`

Thanks for looking into this @rthallamko3 

>  fold the accounting for rocksdb_iter_bytes_read into rocksdb_bytes_read

That is another approach yes, I'd be mindful with that as separating back those metrics in the future mean a breaking change, but assuming yugabyte-db core will stick using iterator pattern on reading blocks then that sounds fine to me.

issueDTO.title: Initial values for stochastic mass-action analysis should be integers
issueDTO.description:
The stochastic mass-action analysis currently takes the same data as the deterministic (ODE-based) mass-action analysis, namely `MassActionProblemData`. However, that isn't quite correct because the stochastic simulation is individual-based, so the states are natural numbers rather than nonnegative real numbers. Currently, the system accepts floats but coerces them to integers before passing them off to `rebop`.

The more correct behavior is:

- Stochastic mass action gets its own type for problem data, in which the initial values are nonnegative integers
- The frontend validates that the initial values provided by the user are in fact nonnegative integers

Whether this counts as a bug or merely a UI/UX issue is a matter of opinion, so I've marked it as both.

repository.description: A collaborative environment for formal, interoperable, conceptual modeling
repository.name: CatColab

summary.main: Implement a separate type for stochastic mass-action problem data with nonnegative integer initial values and validate user input in the frontend.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The initial values provided by the user must be nonnegative integers, validated by the frontend.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about stochastic mass-action analysis, which takes individual-based data and requires initial values to be nonnegative integers. The current system accepts floats but coerces them to integers.

issueDTO.title: Noisy logging from docdb transaction cache lookup loops
issueDTO.description:
Jira Link: [DB-18631](https://yugabyte.atlassian.net/browse/DB-18631)

The transaction cache lookup code has a tight retry loop on transaction status lookup, but logs during a cache lookup retry at WARNING level which is too high volume for a cache miss.  This might actually be logging so aggressively that it impacts performance in extreme cases.

Specifically [this](https://github.com/yugabyte/yugabyte-db/blob/master/src/yb/docdb/transaction_status_cache.cc#L146) should be a VLOG(5) (since below logging the results of the lookup is a VLOG(4)
Conversely [this](https://github.com/yugabyte/yugabyte-db/blob/master/src/yb/docdb/transaction_status_cache.cc#L156) should be a WARNING not an INFO


[DB-18631]: https://yugabyte.atlassian.net/browse/DB-18631?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiNWRkNTljNzYxNjVmNDY3MDlhMDU5Y2ZhYzA5YTRkZjUiLCJwIjoiZ2l0aHViLWNvbS1KU1cifQ

repository.description: YugabyteDB - the cloud native distributed SQL database for mission-critical applications.
repository.name: yugabyte-db

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to reduce noisy logging from docdb transaction cache lookup loops to avoid performance impact.
summary.validationOrRequirement: Log levels should be adjusted according to the code, and the issue is related to performance impact.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue is about adjusting log levels, specifically changing VLOG(4) to VLOG(5) and WARNING to INFO.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to Jira issue DB-18631, and there are links to specific code lines that need to be reviewed.

issueDTO.title: [Feature Request]Fix potential float -> double casting issue and align in expression with comparator "=" implementation
issueDTO.description:
## Feature request

#### Which Delta project/connector is this regarding?
<!--
Please add the component selected below to the beginning of the issue title
For example: [Feature Request][Spark] Title of my issue
-->

- [ ] Spark
- [ ] Standalone
- [ ] Flink
- [x] Kernel
- [ ] Other (fill in here)

### Overview

<!-- Provide a high-level description of the feature request. -->
In https://github.com/delta-io/delta/pull/5186, we are kind of customizing the type check and value comparison among numerics.

Technically we could streamline the implementation via a refactor to
1.figure out the narrowest type
2.transform the expression via implicit cast expression
3.simplify the value comparision.

Doing so today will have 1 test failure fails due to float -> double convertion 84.08 -> 84.08000183105469
We need to investigate this logic in implicit cast and then do refactoring to unify the expression logic
