issueDTO.title: Autogenerate code example / tutorial outputs in documentation
issueDTO.description:
It would be nice to have an automated way of doing the following:
- Generates output of code examples and includes it in the docs
- Error or warn if any of the code examples don't run (or crash) so it's easy to identify what to fix

Something like [nbsphinx](https://nbsphinx.readthedocs.io/en/0.3.2/) does both of the above.
comments: If we generate the code examples, let's make sure the generated code is checked in, otherwise we won't realize when we change something.

I also looked into this. It is quite hard to do so for docs as we don't really have a unified formatting for example code in docs. (@soumith agrees on this I think).

For tutorials, I remember that @soumith mentioned they are already autogenerated.

It shouldn't be too hard to unify the formatting for example code in docs. I think we only need to figure out when code gets printed -- are there other things that I'm not taking into account here?

ie if we get something like
```
>>> x = torch.randn(4, 4)
>>> x.size()
torch.Size([4, 4])
>>> y = x.view(16)
>>> y.size()
torch.Size([16])
>>> z = x.view(-1, 8)  # the size -1 is inferred from other dimensions
>>> z.size()
torch.Size([2, 8])
```
then the rule for printing things is "follow the python interpreter".

One thing that is wrong at times is
```
>>> if True:
...    cool_stuff()
```
Probably either using `...` (like python) or spaces (for copy-paste benefit) is better.
I have a regenerator that successfully checks most of the valid (ha! there are quite a few old "numel matches but the shapes are incompatible" examples that are invalid these days, e.g. `add`) torch docstrings.
I would be very happy to contribute that. My suggestion would be to do this as a test that fails on a mismatch and an optional command "print fixes" or so that outputs the correct things.

I don't want to interfere with any one else cleaning up these things (@li-roy ?), but I'd be happy to have a go at fixing all the docs.

So I put a prototype regenerator/tester for torch/_torch_docs.py that could be a base for [test/test_docs.py](https://github.com/t-vi/pytorch/blob/docstring_regeneration/test/test_docs.py).
It has two modes, one testing torch docstrings (but not with exitcodes yet) and one where it outputs a new torch/_torch_docs.py to stdout.
It uses astor and autopep8 as dependencies and probably runs best on python3.
The would be generated documentation is at [torch/_torch_docs.py](https://github.com/t-vi/pytorch/blob/docstring_regeneration/torch/_torch_docs.py).
Can I take this up?
I will try my hand at it. Can I be assigned, this issue?
You just go ahead, but it'd be neat if you report back if you get stuck or anything.
Okay :)
Hi @t-vi @Jaisu-1 @zou3519 @gchanan @SsnL - is anyone working on this issue anymore ? Could I pick this up ?

issueDTO.title: Add linker step to remove calls to Console.WriteLine
issueDTO.description:
The System.Console assembly is quite expensive size-wise, so an idea might be to add a linker step that can replace calls to Console.WriteLine (and other related Console functions) with nops.

This could be extended to take a user-provided list of functions to replace with nops (this should be fairly trivial to implement if we decided that these functions must be void functions with no ref/out/pointer arguments).

In the particular case for Console.WriteLine, we could have a few modes:

* Disabled.
* Detect & warn.
* Detect & remove (for instance for release builds).

Ref: https://github.com/dotnet/maui/issues/11405

issueDTO.title: Unused frameworks linked into a fully managed linked macOS app
issueDTO.description:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create new XM app.
2. Enable the linker if it's not already linked.
3. Build.
4. Examine which native frameworks the app links with.

### Expected Behavior

A limited set of frameworks required by all apps (Foundation, AppKit).

### Actual Behavior

Quite a few frameworks:

* QuartzCore (CoreAnimation)
* CoreLocation
* Security
* SceneKit
* MapKit
* BusinessChat
* UserNotifications

It's probable that one of more of these frameworks have a valid reason for being used; each would need investigation to see if really needed or not.

We have a test for this: https://github.com/dotnet/macios/blob/58a8d227858bca4c2ace4ed6e2658a8183dac6b1/tests/dotnet/UnitTests/ProjectTest.cs#L3412-L3443

issueDTO.title: Minimal permissions for 'entra app permission' commands
issueDTO.description:
We???re adding a new **Permissions** section to all commands. This section will document the minimal delegated and application permissions required to execute the command.

The goal is to:

* Make it easier to run the CLI with custom app registrations and application permissions.
* Ensure we only document the minimal set of permissions needed.
* Keep documentation consistent by placing the **Permissions** section right before the **Examples** section.
* If there are multiple resources, order them alphabetically
* If there are commands that only support one type of auth (like delegated or app-only), we have an example for that as well. E.g. [m365 planner tenant settings list - Permissions](https://pnp.github.io/cli-microsoft365/cmd/planner/tenant/tenant-settings-list)

### Resources

* [Writing the docs page](https://pnp.github.io/cli-microsoft365/contribute/new-command/writing-the-docs/#permissions)
* [How to document minimal permissions](https://pnp.github.io/cli-microsoft365/contribute/document-minimal-permissions)
* [Planner example 1](https://pnp.github.io/cli-microsoft365/cmd/planner/plan/plan-add#permissions)
* [Planner example 2](https://pnp.github.io/cli-microsoft365/cmd/planner/tenant/tenant-settings-list#permissions)


### Commands in scope

This issue covers the following commands:

* `m365 entra app permission add`
* `m365 entra app permission list`
* `m365 entra app permission remove`
comments: @Jwaegebaert I could work on this.
Awesome, thanks @tmaestrini. I've assigned it to you!

Minimal permissions:

| M365 CLI cmd | Resource | Delegated | Application |
|:---------------|:----------|:-----------|:------------| 
| m365 entra app permission add | Microsoft Graph  | `Application.ReadWrite.All` | `Application.ReadWrite.All` |
| m365 entra app permission list | Microsoft Graph | `Application.Read.All` | `Application.Read.All` |
| m365 entra app permission remove | Microsoft Graph | `Application.ReadWrite.All` | `Application.ReadWrite.All`|

issueDTO.title: Support AWS Elasticsearch IAM authentication by signing requests
issueDTO.description: I'd like to use AWS Elasticsearch as my datastore, using AWS credentials to authenticate. This requires signing requests, so we'd probably need to use the AWS SDK here.
comments: Can you provide the link to signing requirements?

`olivere/elastic` has helpful examples:
- https://github.com/olivere/elastic/wiki/Using-with-AWS-Elasticsearch-Service

FYI - I'm using https://github.com/abutaha/aws-es-proxy
But it has problems at higher throughputs (didn't investigate it yet) and does not work with elasticsearch-hadoop (used by https://github.com/jaegertracing/spark-dependencies)
I assume the proxy is stateless so can be scaled up with a load balancer.
AWS ES now supports VPC endpoints: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/elasticsearch-service/latest/developerguide/es-vpc.html - It's a much better option than publicly available ES and signing requests.
Indeed. I am going to close this.
I think signing requests would make sense even with VPC endpoints. One still might want to protect against tampering with the requests from within the vpc.
Actually not even sure you can disable request signing even in a VPC. Anyone doing this?

When using VPC endpoints you assign a security group to ES. You can control access with security group settings. There is no request signing when you place ES in a VPC (I'm not sure if it's possible to have both VPC and request signing).
@mabn Ah thanks for clarifying. Didn't know that and will try it.

Hey folks. I was wondering if IAM-based authn for ES was still something that is on the table for Jaeger. Reading back on this conversation it seemed to take a different direction and focus on signed vs VPC endpoints.

cc @black-adder
@mabn Any chance you had some thoughts on this based on the previous conversation here? Appreciate any help you can provide!
@black-adder et al, any chance I could get an update on this subject?
I am pretty sure @black-adder doesn't have time to work on this. Need another volunteer.

Sounds good, just wanted to check that this (IAM-based authn for ES) is something y'all would like to see. I can take a stab at it; any pointers on where to start?

Also perhaps a better name for the issue would now be: "Support AWS Elasticsearch IAM authentication". Thanks @yurishkuro!

> any pointers on where to start?

something like this: https://github.com/jaegertracing/jaeger/pull/686/files
Fantastic, thank you!

So I had a misunderstanding above; signing and using IAM based auth are one and the same. Furthermore, this is possible even with VPC-based access to ESS. More details on Amazon's docs here: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/elasticsearch-service/latest/developerguide/es-vpc.html.

The go elastic search client that jaeger uses has some docs on signing requests that make the integration seem fairly reasonable: https://github.com/olivere/elastic/wiki/Using-with-AWS-Elasticsearch-Service. I'm taking a stab at integrating with the AWS go SDKs now.

@wesleyk 
Would it be possible to also have the AWS credentials be retrieved from the ec2 instance IAM role in addition to providing them through configuration like you currently have? 

Creating a session can provide credentials. Something like this:
`
sess, err := session.NewSession(&aws.Config{Region: aws.String(c.AwsConfig.Region)})
`

Then retrieve the credentials:
`
credsValue,  err := sess.Config.Credentials.Get()
`

Thanks,

John

Ah @jmwaniki good idea; in fact I think that could drastically reduce the surface area of AWS-details that are encoded in the configuration API. We would only need to accept a region flag, and if such flag is set then we would provide IAM auth.

A downside there is that an AWS region flag doesn't scream "this enables IAM". We could make that clear in the docs, or maybe we name the flag something like... `.aws.iam_auth_region` or `.aws.iam_auth.region`. Thoughts?

@black-adder with that change, do you feel the API surface area is kept minimal enough? I think we need at least one flag for the client to indicate that they actually do want IAM auth enabled; inferring too much based on what's available in the environment seems potentially troublesome and not backwards compatible with existing clients.

Ah, but you can actually specify the region in that config file as well! So really, we can just have one flag that specifies that the client wants IAM auth enabled.

So we could have a `aws.enable_iam`, and then create a session as John described above.

I like that! If that sounds good to y'all I can update the PR with such changes.

cc @black-adder @jmwaniki

@wesleyk  
That sounds good to me, having a flag that specifies client wants IAM auth enabled `aws.enable_iam` and the other flag for specifying the region `.aws.iam_auth_region`.
Great! I think we don't even need the region because clients can specify that view a local config file.
I'm good with just exposing `aws.enable_iam`, can you make the changes so I can review?
Fantastic! Working on it.
@black-adder PR updated!

@wesleyk 
Just realized the credentials retrieved from the session have a token, that token will expire eventually. 

The credential provider determines when the credentials will expire:
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-go/api/aws/credentials/

The token however is optional for aws static credentials, omitting the token from the static credentials might solve the expiry issue.

Static credentials provider won't expire:
https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go/blob/master/aws/credentials/static_provider.go#L25

Similar to what you had before, with values from the session credentials:
`credsValue, err := sess.Config.Credentials.Get()`

`
creds := credentials.NewStaticCredentials(
			credsValue.AccessKeyID,
			credsValue.SecretAccessKey,
			"",
		)
`

@wesleyk
Using session credentials to create static credentials like I commented above fails to connect to elasticsearch. I tried it and the session token is still required to connect to elasticsearch. In any case, wanted to note that session credentials would need to be refreshed before expiring.
Looks like #1139 provides a fix for this.

For anyone else who stumbles on this issue, I was able to get IAM auth + signed requests working with Jaeger! I followed the hint from [this comment](https://github.com/jaegertracing/jaeger/pull/1036#issuecomment-622134869):
1. Deploy [aws-es-proxy](https://github.com/abutaha/aws-es-proxy) in the same VPC as Jaeger + AWS elasticsearch. Point it at your AWS elasticsearch VPC endpoint. Configure IAM credentials for `aws-ecs-proxy` via env variables or a role or IRSA or whatever 
2. Configure `jaeger-collector` + `jaeger-query` so they point to the proxy instead of AWS elasticsearch directly

Jaeger will send requests to `aws-es-proxy`. `aws-es-proxy` receives a request, signs it, retrieves a result from elasticsearch, and finally returns the response to Jaeger.

@sohan Would you mind sharing what configuration you did to point ` jaeger-collector `+` jaeger-query` to the proxy? 

With the below configuration where in service es-proxy is running in the same namespace(in AWS EKS) as ` jaeger-collector `+` jaeger-query`, I get the fatal error of no Elasticsearch node available.

```
    storage:
      type: elasticsearch
      esIndexCleaner:
        enabled: false
      dependencies:
        enabled: false
      options:
        es:
          index-prefix: "dev"
          server-urls: es-proxy:9200
```

`{"level":"fatal","ts":1627493203.280974,"caller":"command-line-arguments/main.go:75","msg":"Failed to init storage factory","error":"failed to create primary Elasticsearch client: health check timeout: no Elasticsearch node available","stacktrace":"main.main.func1\n\tcommand-line-arguments/main.go:75\ngithub.com/spf13/cobra.(*Command).execute\n\tgithub.com/spf13/cobra@v0.0.7/command.go:838\ngithub.com/spf13/cobra.(*Command).ExecuteC\n\tgithub.com/spf13/cobra@v0.0.7/command.go:943\ngithub.com/spf13/cobra.(*Command).Execute\n\tgithub.com/spf13/cobra@v0.0.7/command.go:883\nmain.main\n\tcommand-line-arguments/main.go:137\nruntime.main\n\truntime/proc.go:204"}`

I was able to make a similar setup working for Logstash which as well does not support irsa yet, but the issue here seems to be that, the requests are not reaching the es-proxy at all.

The above jaeger-operator configuration translates to the below container definition: 

```
spec:
      containers:
      - args:
        - --es.index-prefix=dev
        - --es.server-urls=es-proxy:9200
        - --sampling.strategies-file=/etc/jaeger/sampling/sampling.json
        env:
        - name: SPAN_STORAGE_TYPE
          value: elasticsearch
        - name: COLLECTOR_ZIPKIN_HOST_PORT
          value: :9411
        image: jaegertracing/jaeger-collector:1.22.0
```

In case someone is stuck on the same issue as above, I was able to solve the above by adding `http://es-proxy:9200` instead of just `es-proxy:9200`.

I am now going to look into some alternative methods as well, maybe something like [data-prepper](https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/big-data/getting-started-with-trace-analytics-in-amazon-elasticsearch-service/) and then compare what works best.

Hi,

i was trying to integrate jaeger with opensearch fine grain access. I'm puzzled that why would we want to use proxy than to embed jaeger enable iam authentication feature.

with proxy there is additional maintenance and extra hopes. 

looking at this PR, it seems to deal with aws iam authentication on jaeger https://github.com/jaegertracing/jaeger/pull/1036

i seek enlightenment on this, and real world best practice

> Hi,
>

> 
> with proxy there is additional maintenance and extra hopes.

Indeed, this is a bizarre approach. https://github.com/jaegertracing/jaeger/pull/1139 did not provide a fix at all. The closest we got was the now-closed PR https://github.com/jaegertracing/jaeger/pull/1036.
We introduced SigV4 signing for Prometheus, might as well implement it now for ES/OS. cc @SoumyaRaikwar
Hey @yurishkuro can i give this a try?

summary.main: The main goal of this issue is to support AWS Elasticsearch IAM authentication by signing requests. This requires using the AWS SDK to authenticate and sign requests, and using the AWS Elasticsearch service to store data.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The validation or requirement for this issue is that the AWS Elasticsearch service supports VPC endpoints, which can be used instead of publicly available ES. The issue also requires using the AWS SDK to authenticate and sign requests.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue has been discussed and multiple attempts have been made to fix it. One of the attempts involved using the AWS ES proxy, but it has problems at higher throughputs and does not work with Elasticsearch-Hadoop. Another attempt involved using VPC endpoints, but it does not support request signing. The issue has also been discussed in the context of integrating Jaeger with OpenSearch fine-grain access.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about supporting AWS Elasticsearch IAM authentication by signing requests. It requires using the AWS SDK to authenticate and sign requests. The AWS Elasticsearch service supports VPC endpoints, which can be used instead of publicly available ES. The issue also discusses the possibility of using IAM-based auth for ES even with VPC endpoints. The solution involves creating a session, retrieving the credentials, and then using the credentials to sign requests.

issueDTO.title: Downcast `indices` for sparse matrices if possible on-disk
issueDTO.description:
### Please describe your wishes and possible alternatives to achieve the desired result.


Long standing issue @felix0097 raised a while ago, but we should begin a spec "change" process to begin to allow writing out `indices` of a CSR matrix (or CSC, although less valuable there) whose max value is checked + dtype automatically set optimally.  Nowhere are dtypes specified in https://anndata.readthedocs.io/en/latest/fileformat-prose.html#sparse-array-specification-v0-1-0 so while this isn't a breaking change, it could potentially complicate things downstream.

In other words, the values in `indices` of a CSR matrix are regularly less than `max(uint16)` (because we often dont have more than 30000 or so genes) but are often written as `{u}int32/64` so allowing users to write data optimized for this fact  without breaking downstream pipelines is in our interest. The process for this would be

1. Add a setting to allow this behavior via `anndata.settings.downcast_indices_in_sparse = True` or similar - I would guess the behavior would be "take the max of the incoming `indices` optionally and then write out as the minimum needed dtype"
2. Write tests within `anndata` that ensure reading this data back in doesn't break cupy/scipy sparse
3. Release with this setting as `False`
4. Potentially in the future set to `True`

The downside/complication has been traditionally scipy sparse handling of differing `indptr` + `indices` dtypes but I think that is a manageable problem if we limit ourselves to just io here, and I imagine the performance would be better, even if the data has to be re-upcast into int32 for this compatibility issue, given the lessened io. 

cc @lazappi @ivirshup @keller-mark, happy to produce some dummy data for this for y'all to test.  Let me know if you are aware of any downsides here or if you have commments!
comments:
For **{anndataR}**, I think reading would be ok and we would need to decide whether to implement something similar for writing. Having some test data to confirm would be good though.

What is the main motivation for this, just saving space on disk? I'm wondering if there would be enough of an improvement to justify the extra complexity.

> What is the main motivation for this, just saving space on disk? I'm wondering if there would be enough of an improvement to justify the extra complexity.

Yup, aparse matrices would be cut down in size by ~a factor of 2~ ~40% on disk or so, so io would also be faster at the cost of the potential reallocation of memory. I think the tradeoff is worth it, but also there are other sparse libraries out there that aren't scipy would could in theory handle the differing data types in which case there is no tradeoff, just saved io time.
I have no problem with this from my end, as the reduced array size should be beneficial when loading data via the network and for reduced memory usage in the browser.
Also cc @kaizhang

Hi all,

Here are some test anndata files, have a look at the file names for the case of each file - basically, I generated files for the smallest, middle, and largest values for which `uint{8,16}` would be used under this optimization and then created tests to ensure the dtype is the "smallest" - I also have a smallest for `uint32` but anything larger (or the largest possible value) would blow up memory for writing an anndata object, although I'm happy to generate just the matrix:

[matrices.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/23003353/matrices.zip)

So let me know if you want, for example, a CSR matrix with a billion columns whose `indices` would then be `uint32` instead of `{u}int64`.

repository.description: Annotated data.
repository.name: anndata

summary.main: allow writing out indices of a CSR matrix whose max value is checked + dtype automatically set optimally, reducing disk space and io time
summary.validationOrRequirement: add setting to allow downcasting indices in sparse matrices, ensure reading back in doesn't break cupy/scipy sparse, write tests within anndata, release with setting as false, potentially set to true in the future
summary.attemptedFixes: no attempts mentioned in the issue description
summary.otherNotes: cc @lazappi @ivirshup @keller-mark, @kaizhang; anndataR; matrices.zip test data

issueDTO.description: This `timestamp` field is present in the JSONL file, but the Message types are missing it. Adding it, would be helpful for use cases where the actual Message timestamp is important (ex. displaying a timeline)
comments: I'm happy to submit a PR for this, if there's an agreement this is useful to have

```python
            {"type": "text", "text": "hello"}

}

``` 
`AssistantMessage

model: fake-model
content: [TextBlock(text='hello')]
`

Hi! 👋

I can add the missing `timestamp` field to Message models.

## Analysis
Message models in agent SDK should include timestamp for tracking message timing and sequencing.

## Implementation Plan
1. Add `timestamp` field to Message model (datetime type)
2. Populate on message creation
3. Update serialization/deserialization
4. Add tests for timestamp handling
5. Update type hints + documentation

## Questions
1. ISO 8601 format or Unix timestamp?
2. Should it be optional (backwards compat) or required?
3. Timezone: UTC or preserve original?

## Background
Experienced with Anthropic SDK patterns, maintained EGOS v.2 with comprehensive message tracking.

**Timeline**: 2 days

Happy to implement!

thanks @vikramsingh117 , @enioxt. I already have a PR for this [here](https://github.com/anthropics/claude-agent-sdk-python/pull/261)
@ashwin-ant or @dicksontsai - would love a review on this PR 🙏

@ashwin-ant just bumping this up. hopefully this is nothing controversial and is similar to the other PR I contributed [before](https://github.com/anthropics/claude-agent-sdk-python/pull/166) (basically, extending the types coverage over the serialized json structure). thanks in advance!

Hey, we're looking into how to support this. I think the open PRs are not actually correct, since adding timestamps requires updating the CC binary to output timestamps in its messages over stdio (something it doesn't currently do). We'll have more here soon!
That's visible in the JSONL file but it's not actually coming through the stdio pipe at the moment.

issueDTO.title: Stdlib: Ensure negative indexing behaviour is consistent
issueDTO.description:
In the stdlib, there are some methods (such as `List.insert`, `List.take`, `List.drop`, etc) that fail upon receiving a negative number. This is different than the behavior of something like `String.slice`, which treats the negative index as an offset from the end of the value.

So, I was thinking for consistency sake (and to avoid as many `fail` in the stdlib as possible) that any methods that use indexes in the stdlib should treat negative indexes as an offset from the end of the list. e.g. `List.take(-2, myList)` would take the 2nd-to-last element from the list, and would return `None` if the list doesn't contain enough elements.

Thoughts?
comments: We seem to have taken the approach of accepting negative indexes where possible. We should  repurpose this issue towards making the behaviour consistency. This would also make a good first issue.

repository.description: The Grain compiler toolchain and CLI. Home of the modern web staple. 🌾
repository.name: grain

summary.attemptedFixes: The approach is to repurpose the issue towards making the behavior consistency, and making it a good first issue.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about making the stdlib consistent in handling negative indexing, and making it a good first issue.

issueDTO.title: Onboard GCP support
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

1. Validate KAITO with a BYO GPU node approach on GKE, and
2. Add NAP support for GKE

**Describe the solution you'd like**

- [ ] update supported sku list for gcp
- [ ] integrate with https://github.com/cloudpilot-ai/karpenter-provider-gcp 
- [ ] add workspace example for gcp
- [ ] update installation document

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

**Additional context**
comments:
Validated BYO scenario on GKE. Here are the issues I encountered along the way:

1. Duplicated device-plugin installation (one managed by GKE vs the [other one](https://github.com/kaito-project/kaito/blob/main/charts/kaito/workspace/templates/nvidia-device-plugin-ds.yaml) installed by KAITO)

1. GPU nodes are tainted by default but there is no way to add tolerations to inference workload unless custom pod template is used. Otherwise, user had to manually untaint them.

1. KAITO controller ReplicaSet failed to create pods:

```yaml
...
status:
  conditions:
  - lastTransitionTime: "2025-10-21T19:43:48Z"
    message: 'insufficient quota to match these scopes: [{PriorityClass In [system-node-critical
      system-cluster-critical]}]'
    reason: FailedCreate
    status: "True"
    type: ReplicaFailure
  observedGeneration: 1
  replicas: 0
...
```

Removing KAITO controller's PriorityClass or adding the following ResourceQuota resource to `kaito-workspace` namespace would unblock it:

```yaml
kubectl apply -n kaito-workspace -f - << EOF
apiVersion: v1
kind: ResourceQuota
metadata:
  name: kaito-workspace-quota
spec:
  hard:
    pods: 100
  scopeSelector:
    matchExpressions:
    - operator: In
      scopeName: PriorityClass
      values:
        - system-node-critical
        - system-cluster-critical
EOF
```

---

I also found it better to follow the [GPU Operator guide](https://cloud.google.com/kubernetes-engine/docs/how-to/gpu-operator) rather than specifying `gpu-driver-version` in `--accelerator` during node-pool creation to install GPU driver and related components. The latter doesn't install nvidia-container-toolkit, which is requirement for gpu-feature-discovery.

> Duplicated device-plugin installation (one managed by GKE vs the [other one](https://github.com/kaito-project/kaito/blob/main/charts/kaito/workspace/templates/nvidia-device-plugin-ds.yaml) installed by KAITO)

Would be good if Kaito can detect if device-plugin is already installed. This is going to also be a problem on AKS once the managed device-plugin feature lands. @Fei-Guo

repository.description: Kubernetes AI Toolchain Operator
repository.name: kaito

summary.main: Onboard GCP support
summary.validationOrRequirement: validate KAITO with a BYO GPU node approach on GKE, add NAP support for GKE, update supported sku list for gcp, integrate with https://github.com/cloudpilot-ai/karpenter-provider-gcp, add workspace example for gcp, update installation document
summary.attemptedFixes: Removing KAITO controller's PriorityClass or adding the following ResourceQuota resource to kaito-workspace namespace would unblock it:
summary.otherNotes: Duplicated device-plugin installation (one managed by GKE vs the [other one](https://github.com/kaito-project/kaito/blob/main/charts/kaito/workspace/templates/nvidia-device-plugin-ds.yaml) installed by KAITO), GPU nodes are tainted by default but there is no way to add tolerations to inference workload unless custom pod template is used. Otherwise, user had to manually untaint them., KAITO controller ReplicaSet failed to create pods due to insufficient quota, Removing KAITO controller's PriorityClass or adding the ResourceQuota resource to kaito-workspace namespace would unblock it., The author recommends following the GPU Operator guide rather than specifying gpu-driver-version in --accelerator during node-pool creation to install GPU driver and related components., Kaito should detect if device-plugin is already installed.

issueDTO.title: Humans vs Nations game mode
comments: this would be cool
Make bots imposssible, and the team assignment: 1 team humans, 1 team nations.

I feel like I should mention, even if it's obvious, that this would likely require an increase in the amount of nations that spawn on certain maps. I am wondering how you would see that made considering that up to now, the nations on each map have been deliberately placed and named to correspond to real-world historical or contemporary nations. Would this require the way nations are created to be overhauled for all game modes, or only this one, and even if only limited to this game mode, how much of the api is beholden to the idea of historical, deliberate nations?
Or, we could just have it so there are two levels of complexity: on most maps we'll only have the "main" nations, whilst in this gamemode we'll have the "extras" as well: for example, on the Australia map IIRC there are only the states and territories as nations, but instead in this gamemode we could have multiple cities per state, so the nations would be like: Sydney, Newcastle, Wollongong, Port Macquarie, Albury, Melbourne, Bendigo, Ballart, et cetera.
AI Apocalypse

issueDTO.title: [Bug][a11y]: Tray component lacks visually hidden dismiss button to close the overlay on mobile
issueDTO.description:
### Code of conduct

- [X] I agree to follow this project's code of conduct.

### Impacted component(s)

Tray

### Expected behavior

Like a Picker or ActionMenu, Tray should include a Dismiss button before and after the menu or dialog content so that the overlay can be dismissed using a mobile screen reader.

See the following example from Picker:

https://github.com/adobe/spectrum-web-components/blob/8eb28c866c960b2cf27930cc1eab8f96e2c057d9/packages/picker/src/Picker.ts#L474C19-L521

### Actual behavior

Tray examples lack visually hidden dismiss button to close the overlay on mobile.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### What browsers are you seeing the problem in?

_No response_

### How can we reproduce this issue?

1. Go to '...'
2. Click on '....'
3. Scroll to '....'
4. Check console
5. See error


### Sample code that illustrates the problem

_No response_

### Logs taken while reproducing problem

_No response_
comments: So, in the case where Picker leverages this interface, it does so _within_ a Tray. It feels like most use cases would have a specialized approach to closing (whether these hidden buttons or an actual button, etc.) that would be more appropriate that having this approach baked into the component. Could you share some use cases that might help me see the path you've highlighted with this issue?

> So, in the case where Picker leverages this interface, it does so _within_ a Tray. It feels like most use cases would have a specialized approach to closing (whether these hidden buttons or an actual button, etc.) that would be more appropriate that having this approach baked into the component. Could you share some use cases that might help me see the path you've highlighted with this issue?

I noticed this as a problem in the Menu example for Tray at https://opensource.adobe.com/spectrum-web-components/components/tray/#menu.

We might simply add visually hidden dismiss buttons to this example with an explanation that the button is necessary so that a touch screen reader user can dismiss the Tray. Otherwise, developers will simply copy and paste this code without understanding that it includes no mechanism for closing the Tray with a screen reader.

> I noticed this as a problem in the Menu example for Tray at https://opensource.adobe.com/spectrum-web-components/components/tray/#menu.

This makes sense. Thanks for the additional information.

For clarity on our end, expanding this demo to include the hidden close buttons would address this issue?
SWC-274

Hello @jnurthen in order to help us triage your issue, [can you please review our bug severity classification guide](https://github.com/adobe/spectrum-web-components/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#issue-severity-classification) and provide us with the appropriate severity classification? Please update the label to the correct severity level and remove `SEV missing` label. If we don't hear from you in 2 weeks, we will close this issue as not planned.

issueDTO.title: [Bug][a11y]: Table selected row state without "selects" specified lacks sufficient contrast
issueDTO.description:
### Code of conduct

- [X] I agree to follow this project's code of conduct.

### Impacted component(s)

Table

### Expected behavior

It should be possible to distinguish a selected row from a not selected row even when the selection checkbox is not present.

See React-Spectrum for a positive example: https://react-spectrum.adobe.com/react-spectrum/TableView.html#highlight-selection

### Actual behavior

Selected row state with not `selects` attribute specified lacks sufficient contrast to distinguish selected rows from not selected rows, which is a failure of [WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 1.4.11 Non-text Contrast](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG21/#non-text-contrast)

### Screenshots

_No response_

### What browsers are you seeing the problem in?

_No response_

### How can we reproduce this issue?

1. Go to '...'
2. Click on '....'
3. Scroll to '....'
4. Check console
5. See error


### Sample code that illustrates the problem

_No response_

### Logs taken while reproducing problem

_No response_
comments: Could you elaborate on this issue or provide some steps to reproduce? I took a look at the styles and it looks like a row without a checkbox that is marked with the `selected` attribute does show as a highlighted blue (and in Spectrum CSS when the `is-selected` class is applied). It looks like this may be more of a functionality update? Are you looking for rows to be marked as selected by clicking them like in the React example linked? It doesn't look like SWC currently has the `selectionStyle="highlight"` functionality.
We should check to see if this is still true since Josh's work has finished.

While looking at this, I found a cool package (https://github.com/codemix/deprank) that uses PageRank algorithm to find the 'most important' files in the project and list out dependencies. This can give a good idea of which files are good to tackle first for JS -> TS conversion (and which files may be more challenging).

Here's the command I ran for `desktop-client`:
`npx deprank --ext=".js,.jsx" --deps-first ./packages/desktop-client/src | grep -v "/icons/"`

One thought I had on this (may have been discussed previously). For truly strict typing, the function components themselves should be typed as `FunctionComponent`. Is there any objection to doing so? The only reason I can think would be stylistic preference.

Edit: Decided to look into this and seems [latest consensus is that it's not needed](https://react-typescript-cheatsheet.netlify.app/docs/basic/getting-started/function_components/). Will stick with the `function` style already in use.

issueDTO.title: Bug report: Environment and UI configuration not applied (Cloudflare token / Let's Encrypt email)
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**
When trying to configure parameters such as **Cloudflare API token** or **Let's Encrypt email** via the `.env` file or through the web interface, the values are never applied whereas the API calls in the development tools return 200.

I tested both installation methods:
- Docker
- System package installation

In both cases, the parameters remain **unconfigured**.

However, if I configure them **via the API**, it works.  
But this is not practical, because when I later try to issue a certificate through the API, I get the following error:

```json
{
  "error": "Email not configured in settings"
}
```
Even though my email is already configured.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1) Install Certmate (tested with Docker and system package).
2) Configure Cloudflare token or Let's Encrypt email via .env or web UI.
3) Try to create a certificate via API.
4) Observe error: "Email not configured in settings".

**Expected behavior**
Configuration from .env or UI should be correctly applied and used when issuing certificates.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Debian
 - Browser Brave
 - Version 1.81.137 Chromium: 139.0.7258.158
comments: faced same issue

issueDTO.title: Make 'ExtractZipFromBytesAsync' a static method.
issueDTO.description:
## What version of FlowSynx?
> 1.2.1

## Describe the bug
The method `ExtractZipFromBytesAsync` is currently an instance method:

File: `src/FlowSynx.Infrastructure/PluginHost/Manager/PluginDownloader.cs` line 135

```csharp
private async Task ExtractZipFromBytesAsync(
```

Since this method does not depend on any instance state and only operates on its input parameter, it should be made static.

### Proposed Change:
```csharp
private static async Task ExtractZipFromBytesAsync(
```

#### This change will:
- Clarify that `ExtractZipFromBytesAsync` does not rely on instance state.
- Potentially improve performance slightly by avoiding the need for an instance reference.
- Make it easier to call from other static contexts if you need to.

issueDTO.title: Improve Exception Logging in Plugin Download Extraction
issueDTO.description:
## Summary
Currently, in the plugin download extraction process, the catch block logs errors like this:
File: `src/FlowSynx.Infrastructure/PluginHost/Manager/PluginDownloader.cs` line: 131

```csharp
_logger.LogError(_localization.Get("Plugin_Download_Extraction_ErrorDuringDelete", ex.Message));
```

### Problem:
Passing only `ex.Message` to the logger loses the full exception context, such as stack trace and inner exceptions. This makes debugging and troubleshooting harder.

### Suggested Improvement:
The caught exception should be passed as a parameter to the logger to preserve full exception details:

```csharp
_logger.LogError(ex, _localization.Get("Plugin_Download_Extraction_ErrorDuringDelete", ex.Message));
```

### Benefits:
- Full exception context (stack trace, inner exceptions) is preserved.
- Easier debugging and monitoring.
- Aligns with best practices for structured logging in .NET.

repository.description: Seamless Workflow Automation - Declarative, Extensible, and Fully Controllable
repository.name: flowsynx

summary.main: Improve exception logging in plugin download extraction to preserve full exception context, making debugging and troubleshooting easier.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires a refactoring of the code in PluginDownloader.cs to align with best practices for structured logging in .NET.
summary.attemptedFixes: The suggested improvement is to pass the caught exception as a parameter to the logger to preserve full exception details.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to plugin download extraction in Flowsynx, specifically with exception logging. The current logging approach loses the full exception context, making debugging and troubleshooting harder.

summary.main: the main goal of this issue is to speed up the ES v1 tests, the tests are taking too long, the issue is about speeding up the tests, the problem is with health check timeout, the tests are taking 5 seconds each
summary.validationOrRequirement: the tests should run faster, the tests should not be blocked by health check timeout, the tests should not make goleak error, the tests should be able to disable health checks, the tests should be able to set the timeout to a small value
summary.attemptedFixes: running with profiler, mocking the network response using httptest, initializing the client to error out using FactoryBase, disabling health checks, setting the timeout to 1 second, mocking the http calls and server, trying to disable the healthcheck in case of the below test which still slows down the overall test to 5 seconds
summary.otherNotes: ES v1 tests take too long, the issue is about speeding up the tests, the problem is with health check timeout, the tests are taking 5 seconds each, the main question is what's taking 5 seconds, the ES library stuff, like some checks and then it tries to connect to server, the healthCheck was causing problems and the 5 second timeout even before connecting to the server, upon disabling it in the configuration tests are faster, but sometimes it making a goleak error, the leak is from client itself, the goleak is still there but if i just add a time.Sleep(5* time.Second) to the / path return then the tests pass, setting the timeout to 1 second the tests finish in 1 second indeed, the test is meant to test error handling when not able to connect to the db server, it may be possible to mock something underneath the HTTP client (like roundtripper) to return an error immediately, the test is just testing error handling in the factory, or perhaps we could pass an invalid host name instead, e.g. http://invalid-host-name:9200 which might fail even sooner, the main goal is to speed up the tests, the author is yurishkuro, the repository name is jaegertracing/jaeger

issueDTO.title: Make ComputeChecksum a static method
issueDTO.description:
## What version of FlowSynx?
> 1.2.1

## Describe the bug
The method ComputeChecksum is currently an instance method:

File: `src/FlowSynx.Infrastructure/PluginHost/Manager/PluginDownloader.cs` line 105

```csharp
private string ComputeChecksum(byte[] data)
```

Since this method does not depend on any instance state and only operates on its input parameter, it should be made static.

### Proposed Change:
```csharp
private static string ComputeChecksum(byte[] data)
```

#### This change will:
- Clarify that ComputeChecksum does not rely on instance state.
- Potentially improve performance slightly by avoiding the need for an instance reference.
- Make it easier to call from other static contexts if you need to.

repository.description: Seamless Workflow Automation - Declarative, Extensible, and Fully Controllable
repository.name: flowsynx

summary.main: Make ComputeChecksum a static method to clarify its functionality, improve performance, and make it easier to call from other static contexts.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The method should not rely on instance state and should operate on its input parameter.
summary.attemptedFixes: The proposed change is to make the ComputeChecksum method static, as shown in the code snippet.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to ComputeChecksum method in PluginDownloader.cs file, line 105. The method is currently an instance method but should be made static as it does not depend on any instance state and only operates on its input parameter.

issueDTO.title: Add support for TIME and TIME WITH TIMEZONE types to Presto functions
issueDTO.description:
### Description

The following are the UDF's that use TIME and TIME WITH TIMEZONE (Issue : #14633  ) . Quite a lot of these are simple and straightforward and great as beginner tasks. 


Functions that use TIME
-------------------------
1- date_trunc
2 - cast timestamp to time
3 - date_add
4 - date_diff
5 - millisecond
6 - second
7 - minute
8 - hour
9 - timePlusIntervalDayToSecond
10 - intervalDayToSecondPlusTime
11 - timePlusIntervalYearToMonth
12 - intervalYearToMonthPlusTime
13 - timeMinusIntervalDayToSecond
14 - timeMinusIntervalYearToMonth
15 - subtract
16 - equal
17 - notEqual, lessThan, lessThanOrEqual, greaterThan, greaterthanorEqual, between
18 - castToTimeWithTimeZone
19 - castToTimestamp
20 - castToBigint
21 - castToTimestampWithTimeZone
22 - hashCode
23 - xxHash64
24 - castToTime



Functions that use TIME WITH TIMEZONE
--------------------------------------

1. currentime
2. timeAtTimeZone
3. truncateTimeWithTimeZone
4. date_add
5. date_diff
6. millisecond
7. second
8. minute
9. hour
10. timeWithTimeZonePlusIntervalDayToSecond
11. timeWithTimeZonePlusIntervalYearToMonth
12. intervalDayToSecondPlusTimeWithTimeZone
13. intervalYearToMonthPlusTimeWithTimeZone
14. timeWithTimeZoneMinusIntervalDayToSecond
15. subtract
16. eq,neq, gt, gte, between etc
17. castToTime
18. castToTimestamp
19. castToTimestampWithTimeZone
20. hashCode
21. xxHash64
comments: cc: @anandamideShakyan @aditi-pandit @czentgr @mbasmanova @amitkdutta @majetideepak

cc: @peterenescu 

@mbasmanova  

I believe the simple ones are : 

1.  millisecond
2. second
3. minute
4. hour
5. eq , neq, lt , gt etc (for time, since time is stored as millisutc)
6. castToBigint
7. xxHash64

The timePlusInterval require you to be a little more careful , but doing one of those udf's should allow you to do all the rest of the them. 
The other thing to note is that the cast* functions have a little bit of departure from usual presto semantics (esp TIME with TIMEZONE) as per this issue : https://github.com/prestodb/presto/issues/25957

Working on:

etc.

issueDTO.title: Support GCP Workload Identity in the repository-gcs plugin
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Storing snapshots with the repository-gcs plugin requires a gcp service account key that's stored as a kubernetes secret. We'd like to avoid this secret as it requires additional overhead like periodically rotating the secret for security. GCP's Workload Identity feature would be a better alternative that avoids the need for a secret. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Use GCP's workload identity feature for authentication in the repository-gcs plugin. 

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or features you've considered.

**Additional context**
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.

@vinodhreddyg did you really got this running in opensearch (and not elasticsearch)?

According to https://github.com/elastic/cloud-on-k8s/issues/5230#issuecomment-1008877065 this resp. PR was required for working workload ID support: https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/71239. However that PR came after opensearch was forked and thus is missing in https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/blob/3.1.0/plugins/repository-gcs/src/main/java/org/opensearch/repositories/gcs/GoogleCloudStorageService.java.

### Workaround
One way to get around this is to create a service account key and mount that into your container.

```yaml
apiVersion: iam.cnrm.cloud.google.com/v1beta1
kind: IAMServiceAccount
metadata:
  name: service-account-name
  annotations:
    cnrm.cloud.google.com/project-id: your-project-id
---
apiVersion: iam.cnrm.cloud.google.com/v1beta1
kind: IAMServiceAccountKey
metadata:
  name: service-account-name-key
  annotations:
    cnrm.cloud.google.com/project-id: your-project-id
spec:
  publicKeyType: TYPE_X509_PEM_FILE
  privateKeyType: TYPE_GOOGLE_CREDENTIALS_FILE
  serviceAccountRef:
    name: service-account-name
```

Here's how to mount if using the OpenSearch operator.
```yaml
apiVersion: opensearch.opster.io/v1
kind: OpenSearchCluster
spec:
  general:
    additionalVolumes:
    - name: workload-identity-credentials
      path: "/usr/share/opensearch/config/credentials"
      secret:
        defaultMode: 0655
        secretName: service-account-name-key
  nodePools:
  - env:
    - name: GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS
       value: "/usr/share/opensearch/config/credentials/key.json"
```

issueDTO.title: [REFACTOR] remove redundant fields from webhook_details API and DB models
issueDTO.description:
Below fields are a part of `WebhookDetails` during merchant account creation / updation AND profile creation / updation.

```rust
pub payment_created_enabled: Option<bool>,
pub payment_succeeded_enabled: Option<bool>,
pub payment_failed_enabled: Option<bool>,
```

These fields are not being used in the backend flows and are redundant. These are needed to be removed for keeping the APIs clean.

Currently, they're being consumed in a few components
- hyperswitch-control-center
- hyperswitch postman tests
- hyperswitch cypress tests

Once dependency on these fields is completely removed, these fields can be removed from API and DB models.

issueDTO.title: [MCP] Zendesk Sell
issueDTO.description:
## ??? 🧩 Product Overview

Zendesk Sell  is a sales automation platform that helps sales teams manage leads, contacts, deals, pipelines, and notes. This integration enables workflows to trigger on new or updated sales objects (like deals, contacts, leads), and perform operations such as creating contacts, leads, deals, and notes, updating them, or reacting when a deal stage changes.  


---

## ?????? ?????? Important Note for Contributors

This feature must be submitted as a [Piece](https://www.activepieces.com/docs/developers/building-pieces/piece-definition) following the Activepieces architecture. Submissions not following this format will not be accepted. Please make sure to review the [Piece Development Guidelines](https://www.activepieces.com/docs/developers/building-pieces/overview) before starting development.


---

## 🚨 Triggers  

| Trigger Name | Description | 
|---|---|
| **New Contact** | Fires when a new contact is created in Zendesk Sell.|
| **New Lead** | Fires when a new lead is created. |
| **New Deal** | Fires when a new deal is created.  |
| **Updated Lead** | Fires when an existing lead record is updated.|
| **Updated Contact** | Fires when a contact is updated. |
| **Updated Deal** | Fires when a deal is modified. |
| **Deal Enters New Stage** | Fires when a deal transitions into a specified pipeline stage. |
| **New Note** | Fires when a new note is added to a record (lead, contact, deal).  |

issueDTO.title: Add Version Information and Build Metadata to Application
issueDTO.description:
## Problem
The application has no version information or build metadata, making it difficult to:
- Track which version is running in production
- Debug deployment issues
- Correlate logs/errors with releases
- Verify successful deployments
- Support customers effectively

## Current State
No version information visible anywhere:
- Not in logs
- Not in health check
- Not exposed via API
- Cannot determine what's running

## Proposed Solution
Add build-time version injection and expose it via API.

### 1. Add Version Variables in `main.go`
```go
package main

var (
    version   = "dev"       // Set via -ldflags at build time
    commit    = "none"      // Git commit hash
    buildDate = "unknown"   // Build timestamp
    goVersion = runtime.Version()
)

func main() {
    log.Printf("Starting %s", getVersionInfo())
    // ... rest of startup
}

func getVersionInfo() string {
    return fmt.Sprintf("v%s (commit: %s, built: %s, go: %s)",
        version, commit[:7], buildDate, goVersion)
}
```

### 2. Update Dockerfile for Build-Time Injection
```dockerfile
# Get build args
ARG VERSION=dev
ARG COMMIT=unknown
ARG BUILD_DATE=unknown

# Build with ldflags
RUN go build -ldflags="\
    -X main.version=${VERSION} \
    -X main.commit=${COMMIT} \
    -X main.buildDate=${BUILD_DATE}" \
    -o main ./cmd/server
```

### 3. Add Version Endpoint
```go
// internal/server/router.go
router.GET("/version", func(c *gin.Context) {
    c.JSON(http.StatusOK, gin.H{
        "version":    version,
        "commit":     commit,
        "buildDate":  buildDate,
        "goVersion":  goVersion,
    })
})
```

### 4. Enhance Health Check
```go
router.GET("/health", func(c *gin.Context) {
    c.JSON(http.StatusOK, gin.H{
        "status":    "ok",
        "version":   version,
        "timestamp": time.Now(),
    })
})
```

### 5. Update Makefile for Local Builds
```makefile
VERSION ?= $(shell git describe --tags --always --dirty)
COMMIT ?= $(shell git rev-parse HEAD)
BUILD_DATE ?= $(shell date -u +"%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ")

.PHONY: build
build:
\t@go build -ldflags="\
\t\t-X main.version=${VERSION} \
\t\t-X main.commit=${COMMIT} \
\t\t-X main.buildDate=${BUILD_DATE}" \
\t\t-o bin/server ./cmd/server
```

## Benefits
- ??? Track running versions in production
- ??? Better deployment verification
- ??? Easier debugging and support
- ??? Version endpoint for monitoring tools
- ??? Improved observability
- ??? Professional production readiness

## Implementation Checklist
- [ ] Add version variables to `cmd/server/main.go`
- [ ] Log version info at startup
- [ ] Create `/version` endpoint
- [ ] Update `/health` to include version
- [ ] Update Dockerfile with build args
- [ ] Update Makefile with ldflags
- [ ] Update CI/CD to inject version info
- [ ] Update docker-compose.yml with build args
- [ ] Add version to Swagger docs
- [ ] Update documentation

## Example Output
### Startup Logs
```
Starting GRAB API v1.2.3 (commit: abc1234, built: 2025-10-18T10:30:00Z, go: go1.24.0)
Server starting on :8080
```

### GET /version
```json
{
  "version": "1.2.3",
  "commit": "abc1234567890abcdef1234567890abcdef1234",
  "buildDate": "2025-10-18T10:30:00Z",
  "goVersion": "go1.24.0"
}
```

## References
- [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/)
- [Go Build ldflags](https://pkg.go.dev/cmd/link)
- Standard practice in Kubernetes, Docker Hub, etc.

## Priority
**IMPORTANT** - Improves production operations

## Related Issues
- #15 (Graceful Shutdown) - Part of production readiness
- #11 (Prometheus Metrics) - Can expose version as metric

issueDTO.title: Implement validations to prevent changing TrainingRuntime
issueDTO.description:
### What you would like to be added?

I would like to implement TrainingRuntime webhook validations so that we can prevent any TrainingRuntime changes.

We should implement immutable validations for the following TrainingRuntime and ClusterTrainingRuntimefields:

- `.metadata.labels`: validating webhooks for [TrainingRuntime](https://github.com/kubeflow/trainer/blob/b9c0ee2fb53dfbdbe1b47d880f9da57bffa86b66/pkg/webhooks/trainingruntime_webhook.go) and [ClusterTrainingRuntime](https://github.com/kubeflow/trainer/blob/b9c0ee2fb53dfbdbe1b47d880f9da57bffa86b66/pkg/webhooks/clustertrainingruntime_webhook.go)
- `.metadata.annotations`: validating webhooks [TrainingRuntime](https://github.com/kubeflow/trainer/blob/b9c0ee2fb53dfbdbe1b47d880f9da57bffa86b66/pkg/webhooks/trainingruntime_webhook.go) for [ClusterTrainingRuntime](https://github.com/kubeflow/trainer/blob/b9c0ee2fb53dfbdbe1b47d880f9da57bffa86b66/pkg/webhooks/clustertrainingruntime_webhook.go)
- `.spec`: CRD marker

Note that the controller-tools do not embed the top level metadata fields (`.metadata`) in CRD. So, for labels and annotations validations, we need to implement those by webhooks as opposed to CRD markers.

### Why is this needed?

As we designed Trainer v2 in https://github.com/kubeflow/trainer/tree/master/docs/proposals/2170-kubeflow-trainer-v2#the-training-runtime-api

> The TrainingRuntime is immutable, and so to make a change, a new version of the TrainingRuntime must be created and then the user must change the TrainJob to point to the new version. This provides control as to how changes to runtimes propagate to existing training jobs. For example, when training is running for a long time (e.g. 1-2 months).

In the first iteration, we do not have any kind of version control mechanism. So, to avoid TrainJob disruption by changing TrainingRuntime, we should handle TrainingRuntime and ClusterTrainingRuntime as immutable objects.

### Love this feature?

Give it a 👍 We prioritize the features with most 👍

issueDTO.title: Feature Request: Declarative Preferences in home-manager
issueDTO.description:
I switched my configuration to use the declarative home-manager module for zen-browser, and while it does allow for policies configurations, I noticed that it does not allow for adhoc preferences similar to the programs.firefox.preferences module.

Ideally I would like to set something like this after loading the flake:
`programs.zen-browser.policies.preferrences = {"zen.urlbar.replace-newtab" = false;};`
comments: This is already implemented, you can use the same options as with `programs.firefox` (https://home-manager-options.extranix.com/?query=programs.firefox.&release=master) but with the `programs.zen-browser` prefix
Is this a new change? I tested it when I created this ticket on may 9, and `programs.zen-browser.policies.preferrences` did not work.

> Is this a new change? I tested it when I created this ticket on may 9, and `programs.zen-browser.policies.preferrences` did not work.

It's not a new change 

There is no `policies.preferences` option, the option for the settings is named differently, please check the home manager manual for Firefox options

@pfassina in home manager, the preferences for firefox-based browsers are configured per-profile.
The option you're looking for is `programs.zen-browser.profiles.<name>.settings` (see the reference here https://home-manager-options.extranix.com/?query=settings+firefox&release=master)
If you want to set preferences for all profiles you can use preferences policy https://mozilla.github.io/policy-templates/#preferences

I spent a few hours playing around with all potential options, and I was able to get zen-specific settings in my config through `programs.zen-browser.profiles.<name>.settings`. That path is not very intuitive, at least for me, but it does work. 

Ideally I would like something simpler, but I guess the ownership of changes is kind of blurry between this flake and the upstream firefox module.

While I can get zen-specific settings to work, I would suggest incorporating them in the home manage zen-browser module as options, rather than passing them as text.

> Ideally I would like something simpler, but I guess the ownership of changes is kind of blurry between this flake and the upstream firefox module.

It's implemented in the upstream firefox module that way. The only good way to set the options for all profiles simultaneously that I know is to use the `Preferences` firefox policy (which, as you said, doesn't work for zen specific options, which is probably should be an issue for zen-browser). We can't really do a default options for all profiles otherwise because the browser profiles are not necessarily controlled by home-manager. 


> I would suggest incorporating them in the home manage zen-browser module as options, rather than passing them as text.

I don't think we should do that (at least until stable release): there are many firefox or zen properties and those properties often change, which may break the module
Hey! Any configuration example available to take inspiration?

> Hey! Any configuration example available to take inspiration?

@anotherhadi [use this for reference.](https://github.com/luisnquin/nixos-config/blob/fdf7a58284b78df679e5764c457b441a8a6da6ca/home/modules/browser.nix#L36)

About the extension entries, you will need to search the extensions of your preference in [Add-ons for Firefox](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/)

Go to the page of the extension that you want to declare > See all versions > Copy the link to the latest "Download file" > Download with wget > `unzip -*.xpi -d my-extension` > `cd my-extension` > `cat manifest.json | jq -r '.browser_specific_settings.gecko.id'` > Use that identifier for the entry key, you will end with [something like this.](https://github.com/luisnquin/nixos-config/blob/fdf7a58284b78df679e5764c457b441a8a6da6ca/home/modules/browser.nix#L56) 

I think is fair to add some to documentation in the README.

Some extensions doesn't seem to have a gecko.id
When I use `cat manifest.json | jq -r '.browser_specific_settings.gecko.id'` it returns `null`
Example:
https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/tridactyl-vim
https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/floccus

@atimofeev do you mean this?
https://github.com/luisnquin/nixos-config/blob/a277852e228d50c8f9cf92cb99cc8781bea5a3ce/home/modules/programs/browser/zen.nix#L235

issueDTO.title: SO-101 leader precision
issueDTO.description:
When I back-drive the SO-101 leader joints to teleoperate a follower, the servos ???lock??? into roughly 29 distinct positions per revolution. Because the handle keeps snapping into those detents, it???s almost impossible to capture intermediate values.
This happens even with the leader powered off - it's a physical thing.

Is this expected and is there any way to get around this?

Sending control signals to the follower arm programmatically allows me to move with much higher precision.
comments:
This may be due to the STS3215 servos.
Have you tried other ways of teleoperating your follower arm? like game controllers, keyboard keys, or (if you have one) a Quest VR headset

issueDTO.title: [Ollama] Support new "keep_alive" request parameter
issueDTO.description:
### Problem Statement
Prism currently does not support sending the `"keep_alive"` parameter at the top level of the request payload. As a result, attempts to pass `"keep_alive": "0"` (or any other duration) end up buried inside the `options` object???where Ollama expects it to be at the root of the JSON.


Without `keep_alive` support at the correct level, users cannot control whether models persist in memory (e.g., `"0"` to unload immediately, `-1` to keep indefinitely, or a duration string like `"10m"`).

### Proposal
Extend Prism???s request handling to allow `keep_alive` to be supplied at the top level (alongside `model`, `messages`, `think`, etc.), and ensure it is passed through to the Ollama API unmodified.

### Benefits
- Consistent behavior with Ollama???s API contract.
- Symmetry with the existing `think` parameter. [#534](https://github.com/prism-php/prism/issues/534)
- Real-world control over model loading/unloading to optimize performance and memory usage.

Thank you for considering this essential enhancement.

Do not modify `BaseMenu` and `MessageDialog`. Do not refactor any other areas of the codebase.** ## How to get there - Login as `user@a.com` with password `a` - Go to _Channels_ > _Collections_ - Create a new collection with at least one channel - Click _Options > Edit collection_ - Click _Remove_ button next to the channel - Return and click _Options > Delete collection_ ## Guidance - Find detailed guidance with many code examples in [KDS documentation](https://design-system.learningequality.org/) - Read [the project](https://github.com/learningequality/studio/issues/5060) for more useful references ## Out of Scope - Do not modify `BaseMenu` and `MessageDialog` - Do not refactor any other areas of the codebase ## Expected UI/UX changes - Minor visual differences naturally stemming from the use of KDS ## Acceptance criteria These are general acceptance criteria for the project. For each sub-issue, consider which are relevant. **General** - [ ] The specification above is followed. - [ ] Except for "Expected UI/UX changes," there are no functional or visual differences in user experience. - [ ] There are no `::v-deep` or `/deep/` selectors. - [ ] All user interactions are manually tested with no regressions. - [ ] Pull request includes screenshots. **a11y and i18n** See [the project](https://github.com/learningequality/studio/issues/5060)'s "Guidance" for useful references. - [ ] Implementation meets a11y standards - [ ] All components are LTR and RTL compliant (preview with `pnpm run devserver` since `:hot` doesn't render RTL properly) - [ ] All user-facing strings are translated properly - [ ] The `notranslate` class been added to elements that shouldn't be translated by Google Chrome's automatic translation feature (e.g. user-generated text) - [ ] Mobile experience is reasonable **Unit tests** - [ ] If there is a unit test suite already, it is meaningfully updated (even if tests don't fail) - [ ] If there is no unit test suite, a new one is created. Do not use obsolete `@vue/test-utils` approach. Instead, use `@testing-library/vue` ([Vue Testing Library](https://kolibri-dev.readthedocs.io/en/develop/frontend_architecture/unit_testing.html)).

issueDTO.title: Make --update-in-place default and fallback to unlinking on ETXTBSY
issueDTO.description:
Currently we unlink (delete) the old output file then create a new file in its place. We have a flag `--update-in-place` that overrides this. Generally updating the file in-place is slightly faster, however it can fail if the file is being executed. If the file is a shared object, then update-in-place won't fail, but would likely cause problems for any running program that has that shared object loaded.

So the idea would be that we default to update-in-place for executables, but not for shared objects. Then, if update-in-place fails due to ETXTBSY, we fall back to unlinking the file and creating a new one. If `--update-in-place` is actually specified on the command-line, then we shouldn't fall back if we get ETXTBSY and should instead report the error. `update_in_place` could probably be changed to an `Option<bool>`. We may want to add `--no-update-in-place` to force it to always unlink.

There's also kernel version 6.11, which removed the ETXTBSY error (it was restored in 6.12). We could detect that and always unlink, but it doesn't seem necessary, since 6.11 is not widely used anymore and is likely to get even less used as time goes by.

Because `--update-in-place` isn't the default, it hasn't had a lot of testing. There's a non-zero chance that we have bits of our writing code that don't write to some bytes of the file. This would be problematic if the file isn't initialised with all zeros. So I think a first step for this issue is to write a test that runs wild twice. Run once with the output file not existing or with `--no-update-in-place`. Read the contents of the file for later use. Overwrite the file with some random, non-zero byte. Possibly extend the file a bit larger than it was while we're at it. Run again with `--update-in-place`. Read the file again and check that it's identical to the bytes we read the first time. The simplest place to add this test is by making it an optional mode in `integration_test.rs`. i.e. add a test directive, that when turned on, performs this testing when linking with wild. We can then do a one-off test with it on for all tests, but then probably just leave it on for one or a few.
comments: Hey, I'll take a try on this one, but I'm quite new to linkers so the chances that I'll bother you with questions are high
Great! Feel free to ask questions here as needed
If `--update-in-place` is specified on the command-line and the output file is a shared object, should we silently change to unlink and replace or just return an error?

I think if `--update-in-place` is specified and we're outputting a shared object, we should just probably update in-place. The user is unlikely to provide the flag and if they do, they hopefully know what they're doing. So I'd say whether it's a shared object should just affect the default if no flag is specified.

issueDTO.title: Sequence puzzle object sprite has 0.7 scale factor
issueDTO.description: I hadn't noticed before today, but in 9defdbab361471bd92d371357f990b490c62e5f3 which swapped from a placeholder rock to a fabric rock asset, a scale of (0.7, 0.7) was applied to the AnimatedSprite2D. This makes it harder to design new assets for sequence puzzle objects, because when used in-game they will be scaled relative to the player. To address this I would suggest working as follows: 1. Reset the scale factor in `res://scenes/game_elements/props/sequence_puzzle_object/sequence_puzzle_object.tscn` to (1, 1) 2. Find all scenes that reference it: 3. In each scene, determine what adjustments need to be made, if any. I expect that the Stella scene will need the most changes because the six objects are carefully positioned to line up with a turtle asset. Other scenes will probably be OK with a bit of tweaking of positions. ### XP Summary (total 300) | Subdomain | Skill | XP | | - | - | - | | Game Design: Game Feel & UX | Problem Solving | 150 | | Game Design: Game Feel & UX | Creativity & Design Thinking | 75 | | Game Design: Game Feel & UX | Technical Literacy | 75 |
comments: Although this is strictly speaking a breaking change, I think the impact on any unmerged quests that are subsequently merged is likely to be pretty small and fixable easily enough; whereas keeping this behaviour causes confusion to every future person who designs an asset for their sequence puzzle and then wonders why it's come out so small.
I plan to work on this.

```
if chosen_quest == null:
```

issueDTO.title: macOS: QuickLook with new API since macOS 15 (Sequoia)
issueDTO.description:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Problem description

The QuickLook functionality introduced to FreeCAD with [this](https://github.com/FreeCAD/FreeCAD/pull/7491) pull request works only until macOS 10.14. With the macOS Sequoia release a new API has to be used.

`Support for deprecated Quick Look Generator plugins is being removed. To provide previews and thumbnails for your custom file types, migrate to Quick Look Preview Extension and Thumbnail Extension API. (116791365)`

See https://developer.apple.com/documentation/macos-release-notes/macos-15-release-notes

### Full version info

```shell
OS: macOS 15.2
Architecture: x86_64
Version: 1.0.0.39109 (Git) Conda
Build type: Release
Branch: (HEAD detached at 1.0.0)
Hash: 2fcc5317fe3aee96ca73475986a577719fc78e20
Python 3.11.10, Qt 5.15.15, Coin 4.0.3, Vtk 9.3.0, OCC 7.8.1
Locale: C/Default (C)
Stylesheet/Theme/QtStyle: FreeCAD Dark.qss/FreeCAD Dark/Fusion
Installed mods: 
  * Trails 2022.1.0
  * ThreadProfile 1.81.0
  * Reporting
  * Behave-Dark-Colors 0.0.1
  * dodo
  * DynamicData 2.70.0
  * parts_library
  * fcgear 1.0.0
  * workfeature
  * fasteners 0.3.40
  * lattice2 1.0.0
  * 3D_Printing_Tools
  * Assembly4 0.11.10
```


### Subproject(s) affected?

None

### Anything else?

_No response_

### Code of Conduct

- [X] I agree to follow this project's Code of Conduct
comments: will the new API break it on macOS 13?
cc @MatthiasWM any chance you could weigh-in here ?
Thanks for the update. I will try to find some time to look at this tonight and reply here.

> Thanks for the update. I will try to find some time to look at this tonight and reply here.

Any updates on this @MatthiasWM? :)
@MatthiasWM bump
Sorry, real life got in the way. I will try to give this another shot this weekend, but no promises.
No pressure, thanks for your efforts.

Hi, I've just pushed a new preview app extension for macOS 15+: https://github.com/graelo/FreeCAD-preview-extension. I did this for me but hoping this could be integrated in the FreeCAD bundle.

It's simple: using Swift and the new API, the extension simply opens the FCStd file and displays the Thumbnail.png. 

I've been using it locally for a couple months.

I was looking at the previous PR on the topic 3 years ago:
- https://github.com/FreeCAD/FreeCAD-Bundle/pull/136
- https://github.com/FreeCAD/FreeCAD/pull/7491
but the integration work seems too complex for my limited understanding of this part. Can someone help for this part? @luzpaz @MatthiasWM maybe (sorry for tagging)

PS: I set the license to MIT, I hope this is not an issue. I can still change it.
PS2 : I set an icon, derived from the original logo (just added a looking glass), this can be dropped.

Thanks!

Could this be integrated in FreeCAD?
@hyarion FYI
@graelo would you like to create a PR with your new implementation?
Hi, I'd love to, but I'm not sure where it should fit in the existing codebase. Can you provide an overview?
I would of course drop the existing app, only the extension is useful.

To be more explicit about my lack of understanding:
- I don't see why the previous PR was linked to conda for bundling the extension. Not criticizing at all, it got me lost
- How could I hook the app extension into the macOS FreeCAD app.
@adrianinsaval @oursland any ideas?

The location of the current QuickLook plugin is here: https://github.com/FreeCAD/FreeCAD/tree/main/src/MacAppBundle/QuickLook

This is installed into the `Contents/Library/QuickLook` path within `FreeCAD.app` by this `CMakeLists.txt`: https://github.com/FreeCAD/FreeCAD/blob/main/src/MacAppBundle/CMakeLists.txt

Is it possible to adapt this to the new QuickLook extension?

I was wondering why Quick Look Preview and thumbnails didn't work on MacOS.

This would be a nice feature to have fixed.

I have tried @graelo extension and can only seem to get half of it to work. After enabling his app's extension there are Quick Look Previews, but there don't seem to be Quick Look Thumbnails. Still, having Preview is better than nothing.
I've noticed that most other apps add two Quick Look Extensions -- one for Previews and one for thumbnails. This is on MacOS Sequoia.

Hi, that's a good point, I had not thought of thumbnails: I only thought of previews.

I can look at adding this if there's interest, but honestly at the same time I'm investing additional time, I'd also like to know if there's a path to integrate this into FreeCAD (my initial question).
@chennes any idea?

When I build I get warnings about using deprecated APIs, presumably related to this functionality. The code is in
https://github.com/FreeCAD/FreeCAD/tree/main/src/MacAppBundle/QuickLook

Blender only has one Quicklook extension, like @graelo implementation. They use it to produce thumbnails, Quick Look Preview for .blend files is a scaled up (full resolution?) thumbnail. Blender's thumbnail seem to to have low resolution, I can't tell if it's the full thumbnail PNG or just the icon zoomed in. If it's the full PNG I don't see a need for two Quick Look extensions -- changing Graelo's implementation to generate only thumbnails would fix both thumbnails and previews. If only I knew how to do that for testing. The only reason to have a seperate Quick Look preview extension seems to be extra functionality, like scrolling through LibreOffice documents and rotating 3D renders. With FreeCAD, the use seems limited as discussed [here](https://forum.freecad.org/viewtopic.php?f=10&t=71803). Unless something changed and we can now have FreeCAD quickly generate a 3D model for use in Quick Look preview.

Hi, I now have a working thumbnail preview and I kept the full size preview too (it looks better than the scaled thumbnail). I renamed the project to remove Thumbnail in the App name, even if this is a toy app meant to disappear, I found my initial naming to be confusing. In the end QuickLook Preview is for the rich preview (even though it is static here, as @TH1813254617 pointed out). Thumbnail Preview is for the finder thumbnails. I'll push the code onto my repo within a few hours. ## The new QLThumbnail preview and ## The existing QuickLook Preview
After the code is pushed, I'll investigate how to embed this instead of the existing implementation (thanks @chennes) and report back here. Cheers

## Description
Create a GitHub Copilot instructions file to provide context and guidance for AI-assisted development in this repository, to help future contributors.

## Requirements
- Create `.github/copilot-instructions.md` file
- Include project-specific context about the AI robo-advisor
- Add coding standards and conventions
- Specify preferred libraries and frameworks (Python, LangGraph, financial APIs)
- Include domain-specific terminology for finance and investing

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] File created at `.github/copilot-instructions.md`
- [ ] Contains project overview and purpose
- [ ] Includes coding guidelines and best practices
- [ ] Specifies financial domain context

issueDTO.title: [Bug]: Issue with IllegalStateException in `STORAGE_WRITE_API` method in `BigQueryIO`
issueDTO.description:
### What happened?

I am running a Beam pipeline in Google Dataflow (Beam SDK version `2.56.0`) that reads messages from Pub/Sub and writes data to a BigQuery table using the STORAGE_WRITE_API method. 
This is the BigQueryIO configuration I'm using:
```
BigQueryIO.write<KV<String, TableRow>>().to(
                BigQueryDestination(...)
            )
                .withFormatFunction { it.value } // Get TableRow
                .withCreateDisposition(BigQueryIO.Write.CreateDisposition.CREATE_IF_NEEDED)
                .withWriteDisposition(BigQueryIO.Write.WriteDisposition.WRITE_APPEND)
                .withFailedInsertRetryPolicy(InsertRetryPolicy.retryTransientErrors())
                .withMethod(BigQueryIO.Write.Method.STORAGE_WRITE_API)
                .withTriggeringFrequency(Duration.standardMinutes(5))
                .withAutoSharding()
                .ignoreUnknownValues()
```
I observed an IllegalStateException error in the pipeline logs when running load test:
```
Error message from worker: java.lang.RuntimeException: java.lang.IllegalStateException
        org.apache.beam.sdk.io.gcp.bigquery.StorageApiWritesShardedRecords$WriteRecordsDoFn.lambda$process$12(StorageApiWritesShardedRecords.java:608)
```
