comments: Is the error transient?

> Is the error transient?
No, the error is not transient
It occurs frequently in the pipeline logs
![aaaa](https://github.com/apache/beam/assets/133836482/a0675348-84ee-49fa-aedf-d7501f6fe8c0)

Since this is a streaming job, is the job often stuck? 
I also suggest you open a GCP support ticket (https://cloud.google.com/dataflow/docs/support/getting-support). 
I have seen some issues similar to this but they are often caused by some Java package mismatches.

The trackstace points to here: https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/8c6e1a4654bced7bf732e1a46092908580da561b/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigquery/BigQueryServicesImpl.java#L1459

indicates the client is already closed when one trying to write records via "StorageApiWritesShardedRecords".

"closed" could only be true when StreamAppendClient.close is called.

Sounds like some racing condition happened there.

Note that "WritesShardedRecords" is used to write spilled records that not handled by "WritesUnShardedRecords" and is a less execised code.

In any case, open a support ticket so cloud support could inspect your job ID. I see a public bug opened for https://b.corp.google.com/issues/345352979 this is not a usual process

> The trackstace points to here:
> 
> https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/8c6e1a4654bced7bf732e1a46092908580da561b/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigquery/BigQueryServicesImpl.java#L1459
> 
> indicates the client is already closed when one trying to write records via "StorageApiWritesShardedRecords".
> 
> "closed" could only be true when StreamAppendClient.close is called.
> 
> Sounds like some racing condition happened there.
> 
> Note that "WritesShardedRecords" is used to write spilled records that not handled by "WritesUnShardedRecords" and is a less execised code.
> 
> In any case, open a support ticket so cloud support could inspect your job ID. I see a public bug opened for https://b.corp.google.com/issues/345352979 this is not a usual process

I created a GCP support ticket.

There are two places closing the client:

https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/2ddfcfb1c18020d0c01c7ebfe5d898a5b8a303b6/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigquery/StorageApiWriteUnshardedRecords.java#L392

https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/2ddfcfb1c18020d0c01c7ebfe5d898a5b8a303b6/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigquery/StorageApiWritesShardedRecords.java#L517

Apparent racing condition most likely client already marked closed here, then in 

https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/2ddfcfb1c18020d0c01c7ebfe5d898a5b8a303b6/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigquery/StorageApiWritesShardedRecords.java#L600

it tries to use the client and fails precondition.

It's hard to locate where the client get closed (async and lambda programming code style). Basically, there is a APPEND_CLIENTS cache:

https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/2ddfcfb1c18020d0c01c7ebfe5d898a5b8a303b6/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigquery/StorageApiWritesShardedRecords.java#L181

removal of cache item will trigger `appendClientInfo.close` which calls `getCloseAppendClient().accept(client)` that is the code above.

Then what happens is the cache entry contains the client get invalidated before it's going to be used again.

I get the same error  with `apache-beam 2.65.0`. I also read from PubSub and write to BigQuery. I use the Python SDK (though behind the curtains the PubSub and BigQuery connectors just call the java implementations).

We're still seeing this with the latest apache-beam 2.66.0 release using the `STORAGE_WRITE_API` method with the python sdk and the GCP dataflow runner. The error log from the dataflow workers are below:
```
"Error message from worker: generic::unknown: org.apache.beam.sdk.util.UserCodeException: java.lang.RuntimeException: java.lang.IllegalStateException
	org.apache.beam.sdk.util.UserCodeException.wrap(UserCodeException.java:39)
	org.apache.beam.sdk.io.gcp.bigquery.StorageApiWritesShardedRecords$WriteRecordsDoFn$DoFnInvoker.invokeProcessElement(Unknown Source)
	org.apache.beam.fn.harness.FnApiDoFnRunner.processElementForWindowObservingParDo(FnApiDoFnRunner.java:731)
	org.apache.beam.fn.harness.data.PCollectionConsumerRegistry$MetricTrackingFnDataReceiver.accept(PCollectionConsumerRegistry.java:349)
	org.apache.beam.fn.harness.data.PCollectionConsumerRegistry$MetricTrackingFnDataReceiver.accept(PCollectionConsumerRegistry.java:276)
	org.apache.beam.fn.harness.BeamFnDataReadRunner.forwardElementToConsumer(BeamFnDataReadRunner.java:228)
	org.apache.beam.sdk.fn.data.BeamFnDataInboundObserver.multiplexElements(BeamFnDataInboundObserver.java:231)
	org.apache.beam.fn.harness.control.ProcessBundleHandler.processBundle(ProcessBundleHandler.java:527)
	org.apache.beam.fn.harness.control.BeamFnControlClient.delegateOnInstructionRequestType(BeamFnControlClient.java:150)
	org.apache.beam.fn.harness.control.BeamFnControlClient$InboundObserver.lambda$onNext$0(BeamFnControlClient.java:115)
	java.base/java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:572)
	java.base/java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:317)
	org.apache.beam.sdk.util.UnboundedScheduledExecutorService$ScheduledFutureTask.run(UnboundedScheduledExecutorService.java:163)
	java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1144)
	java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:642)
	java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:1583)
Caused by: java.lang.RuntimeException: java.lang.IllegalStateException
	org.apache.beam.sdk.io.gcp.bigquery.StorageApiWritesShardedRecords$WriteRecordsDoFn.lambda$process$12(StorageApiWritesShardedRecords.java:661)
	org.apache.beam.sdk.io.gcp.bigquery.StorageApiWritesShardedRecords$WriteRecordsDoFn.process(StorageApiWritesShardedRecords.java:934)
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException
	org.apache.beam.vendor.guava.v32_1_2_jre.com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkState(Preconditions.java:496)
	org.apache.beam.sdk.io.gcp.bigquery.BigQueryServicesImpl$WriteStreamServiceImpl$1.pin(BigQueryServicesImpl.java:1510)
	org.apache.beam.sdk.io.gcp.bigquery.StorageApiWritesShardedRecords$WriteRecordsDoFn.lambda$process$12(StorageApiWritesShardedRecords.java:653)
	org.apache.beam.sdk.io.gcp.bigquery.StorageApiWritesShardedRecords$WriteRecordsDoFn.process(StorageApiWritesShardedRecords.java:934)
	org.apache.beam.sdk.io.gcp.bigquery.StorageApiWritesShardedRecords$WriteRecordsDoFn$DoFnInvoker.invokeProcessElement(Unknown Source)
	org.apache.beam.fn.harness.FnApiDoFnRunner.processElementForWindowObservingParDo(FnApiDoFnRunner.java:731)
	org.apache.beam.fn.harness.data.PCollectionConsumerRegistry$MetricTrackingFnDataReceiver.accept(PCollectionConsumerRegistry.java:349)
	org.apache.beam.fn.harness.data.PCollectionConsumerRegistry$MetricTrackingFnDataReceiver.accept(PCollectionConsumerRegistry.java:276)
	org.apache.beam.fn.harness.BeamFnDataReadRunner.forwardElementToConsumer(BeamFnDataReadRunner.java:228)
	org.apache.beam.sdk.fn.data.BeamFnDataInboundObserver.multiplexElements(BeamFnDataInboundObserver.java:231)
	org.apache.beam.fn.harness.control.ProcessBundleHandler.processBundle(ProcessBundleHandler.java:527)
	org.apache.beam.fn.harness.control.BeamFnControlClient.delegateOnInstructionRequestType(BeamFnControlClient.java:150)
	org.apache.beam.fn.harness.control.BeamFnControlClient$InboundObserver.lambda$onNext$0(BeamFnControlClient.java:115)
	java.base/java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:572)
	java.base/java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:317)
	org.apache.beam.sdk.util.UnboundedScheduledExecutorService$ScheduledFutureTask.run(UnboundedScheduledExecutorService.java:163)
	java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1144)
	java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:642)
	java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:1583)

passed through:
==>
    dist_proc/dax/workflow/worker/fnapi_service_impl.cc:1341"
```
@jbandoro possible to let us know how to reproduce this?

Similar to the OP but with the python sdk, we're reading messages from a Pub/Sub subscription (with `beam.io.gcp.pubsub.ReadFromPubSub`), parsing the records and then writing to BigQuery with:

```python
        parsed_messages | "Write to BigQuery" >> beam.io.WriteToBigQuery(
            table=FULL_TABLE_ID,
            schema=TABLE_SCHEMA,
            write_disposition=beam.io.BigQueryDisposition.WRITE_APPEND,
            method=beam.io.WriteToBigQuery.Method.STORAGE_WRITE_API,
            with_auto_sharding=True,
        )
```

Using `apache-beam==2.66.0` with the DataflowRunner on a streaming pipeline with the `streaming_mode_at_least_once` mode. We're using a custom dataflow image following the instructions in the [docs](https://cloud.google.com/dataflow/docs/guides/build-container-image). 

From my testing setting `with_auto_sharding` to False still resulted in the the errors I posted in the comment above. One arg for `WriteToBigQuery` that seemed to reduce the frequency of the errors was to set `triggering_frequency` to a value above 5 seconds. I also set some custom metric counters and it doesn't appear that we're loosing any data as the retries by the workers are working and all the streaming data is landing in the BigQuery sink.

Let me know if there's anything else that would be helpful or steps I can take, thanks!

summary.main: The issue is related to a racing condition in the BigQueryIO code, specifically in the StorageApiWritesShardedRecords class. The client is being closed before it's being used, causing an IllegalStateException. The issue is not specific to the Python SDK, but rather a problem with the underlying Java code.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue is related to a racing condition in the BigQueryIO code, specifically in the StorageApiWritesShardedRecords class. The client is being closed before it's being used, causing an IllegalStateException.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue has been reported to the Apache Beam community and a support ticket has been opened with Google Cloud Support. The error is intermittent and can be reproduced by using the STORAGE_WRITE_API method with the Python SDK and the GCP Dataflow runner. The issue has been reported to the Apache Beam community and a support ticket has been opened with Google Cloud Support.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to a racing condition in the BigQueryIO code, specifically in the StorageApiWritesShardedRecords class. The client is being closed before it's being used, causing an IllegalStateException. The issue is not specific to the Python SDK, but rather a problem with the underlying Java code. The error is intermittent and can be reproduced by using the STORAGE_WRITE_API method with the Python SDK and the GCP Dataflow runner. The issue has been reported to the Apache Beam community and a support ticket has been opened with Google Cloud Support.

issueDTO.title: Visual loading indicator fallback while assets are loading
issueDTO.description:
### Increasing access

This proposal aims to make p5.js more accessible and user-friendly, particularly for non-English speakers, by replacing the text-based "Loading" message with a simple loading animation.

### Which types of changes would be made?

- [ ] Breaking change (Add-on libraries or sketches will work differently even if their code stays the same.)
- [ ] Systemic change (Many features or contributor workflows will be affected.)
- [X] Overdue change (Modifications will be made that have been desirable for a long time.)
- [ ] Unsure (The community can help to determine the type of change.)

### Most appropriate sub-area of p5.js?

- [ ] Accessibility
- [ ] Color
- [X] Core/Environment/Rendering
- [ ] Data
- [x] DOM
- [ ] Events
- [ ] Image
- [ ] IO
- [ ] Math
- [ ] Typography
- [ ] Utilities
- [ ] WebGL
- [ ] Build process
- [ ] Unit testing
- [X] Internationalization
- [ ] Friendly errors
- [ ] Other (specify if possible)

### What's the problem?

Currently, p5.js displays a text-based "Loading" message in the top-left corner of the page during the execution of the `preload()` function. This approach is not very visually engaging and can be confusing for end-users who do not understand English or have visual impairments. 

A p5.js coder can replace "Loading" with a custom animation. This is mentioned in the [`preload()`](https://p5js.org/reference/#/p5/preload) and the [p5.js overview page](https://github.com/processing/p5.js/wiki/p5.js-overview#loading-screen) but this option is still relatively hidden and not particularly beginner friendly.  See this [Coding Train tutorial on loading animations](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UWgDKtvnjIU).

### What's the solution?

Replace the text-based "Loading" message with a visual loading animation. This animation could be a simple, universally recognized loading indicator (e.g., spinning circle) that provides a visual cue to users that content is being loaded without relying on text. An animated loader also better conveys the fact that _something is happening_. We can use the [`afterPreload` lifecycle event](https://github.com/processing/p5.js/issues/6422) to trigger hiding the loading animation. Possibly, the loading animation itself could be user-overridable via a `preloadAnimation()` function.

### Pros (updated based on community comments)

**Accessibility:** Enhances p5.js accessibility by providing a language-independent loading indicator.
**User Experience:** Improves the user experience with a more engaging and informative visual cue during load times.
**Internationalization:** Supports p5.js's goal of being globally accessible by removing language barriers in the loading process.
**Visual identity:** The default loading animation could be an opportunity to include subtle elements of the p5.js visual identity like the pink color.

### Cons (updated based on community comments)

**Intrusivity:** Depending on its design, the loading animation may be perceived as intrusive. We can mitigate this by making it easy to change the animation or deactivate it, and add examples on the `preload()` reference page.

### Proposal status

Under review
comments:
Thank you for bringing this up @SableRaf . I find your proposal satisfactory, and all the mentioned benefits make sense. Initially, I thought using text for loading, instead of animation, was to prevent confusion for users creating sketches and animations in p5.js. 

I apologize if I am wrong but do you think using a loading animation might give a similar appearance to a sketch, causing potential confusion?? 

> The default loading animation could be an opportunity to include subtle elements of the p5.js visual identity like the pink color.

What I think using this may also help in avoiding such misunderstandings.

@SableRaf If we adopt async/await per #6767 would a loading indicator still be needed? With async/await there will not be a need for a separate `preload()` function and data loading probably will feel similar to the synchronous behaviour of Processing for example.

Thanks for your reply @limzykenneth. I'm not sure I fully understand the implications of using async/await for loading so take my feedback with a pinch of salt but, in cases where large files or many assets are being loaded, would a loading indicator could still be beneficial to inform users that the process is ongoing? Maybe it can be less intrusive, like a loading spinner in the top left corner.

@SableRaf I was thinking something along those lines if we are to still retain the loading indicator with async/await. I believe that is possible, just wondering if it is something we want to keep around. I don't quite remember but does Processing do anything similar when waiting for slow file reads?

> does Processing do anything similar when waiting for slow file reads?

Not that I'm aware, but file reads are probably faster with Java on Desktop, right?

Yes, certainly with file read from disk definitely faster than file request over the network. So I think there are a few options:

* Full canvas blocking loading indicator - Similar to what we have now, perhaps visual instead, cons would be that it can seem intrusive
* Loading spinner/graphic in corner - Less intrusive (although not entirely unintrusive)
* Opt-in or Opt out for the above two - As part of the loading API, sketch author can decide whether to use the loading indicator or not through an additional argument. It provides choice but slightly complicates the API, also it is unclear whether loading indicator should be opt in or opt out
* No loading indicator at all - Likely closest to semantic JavaScript but long loading time can be misunderstood as performance issue

Thanks @limzykenneth, that sums it up perfectly!

I just thought of a way to make this work as opt-in in a relatively non-intrusive way: what if when files take a long time to load, we throw a warning message via the FES suggesting that the sketch author use the optional loader? For example:

> 🌸 It looks like your file is taking a bit longer to load than usual ??? Consider using `loadingAnimation()` to display a loading animation while your files are being loaded.

This way people would only be exposed to the feature when they need it.

Thanks for the discussion and ideas everyone, it would be great to see this implemented. **This proposal has been accepted for implementation and is looking for a volunteer!** This is a nice stand-alone feature, so it would be great to keep this open for new contributors - if you're already an established contributor, please check first if there are other issues ["Ready for Work" in p5.js 2.x](https://github.com/orgs/processing/projects/21/views/8).

Solutions can include either/or:

1. Tutorial for beta.p5js.org (on p5.js-website 2.0 branch) that shows how to create a custom loading animation with async. For example, a background color and a simple text, which the user can control. As @quinton-ashley suggests, "The tutorial could be suggested by p5 FES to users that use a lot of load* functions in their sketch."
2. A CSS loading animation with cursor effects **add-on library,** which can provides `loadingAnimation` as a way to parameterize CSS loading. This would be a very small library, just the 1 method, but by making it separately first, it makes it possible to test it, iterate on what the parameters should be, and discuss it before making core API changes. **Addon must be compatible with both 1.x and 2.0;** [there's a short example how to do that here](https://github.com/processing/p5.js-compatibility?tab=readme-ov-file#using-registerpreloadmethod-in-an-add-on-libraries).

🌼  Please keep in mind the original proposal's focus on i18n - for the tutorial solution, making some issues to request Tutorial's translation into other languages would be great; for the library, I think it's a bit more open how multi-language support can be provided. For example, rather than a spinning star animation, it could be a very simple animation of some "loading" text in many languages? Maybe it can be more creative than "loading?" 🌐 

**If you're new to p5.js contribution, welcome!** Please be sure to read through the [contributor guidelines](https://p5js.org/contribute/contributor_guidelines/), and keep in mind that you should not file a pull request (or start working on code changes) without a corresponding issue or before an issue has been approved for implementation and assigned.

_PS: This message is part of cleaning up the [p5.js 2.0 roadmap](https://github.com/orgs/processing/projects/21) prior to release, to make outstanding more more approachable for new contributors. You can join the conversation about this new version on [this Discourse thread](https://discourse.processing.org/t/dev-updates-p5-js-2-0-you-are-here/46130) or this [GitHub thread](https://github.com/processing/p5.js/issues/7488)!_

Hi @ksen0 and thanks for the summary!

On the tutorial idea, I've updated a 1.x demo sketch of mine for async/await [here](https://editor.p5js.org/SableRaf/sketches/Nb0WPmyI6). It could potentially be used as a basis for a tutorial on custom loaders. I'm curious if that's the direction you had in mind.

About the loading text idea, I'm wondering if it???s necessary? Visual loading indicators (not necessarily a spinning star) are pretty common, and I think most people would recognize them without text. But I know you had some thoughts about this, so I???m open to whatever makes most sense 😌

>  For example, rather than a spinning star animation, it could be a very simple animation of some "loading" text in many languages? Maybe it can be more creative than "loading?" 🌐

@ksen0 I like your idea! Including a spinning p5.js asterisk, the p5.js logo, or some other kind of branding would help to make it clear what's loading though.

@SableRaf The concern with a text-less loader from @perminder-17 was that people may confuse it for the art itself in cases where that could be initially ambiguous. Would you disagree?

Also I was under the impression that the loader would just cover individual p5 canvases and not the full page.

If we assume p5 users want viewers to be able to see their canvas content as soon as possible maybe just cutting to it or having a very short fade out may be preferable.

> it would be great to keep this open for new contributors

I have some other suggestions for anyone that wants to implement this feature:

- the mouse cursor could also be set to indicate loading when hovering over the canvas that's loading (or just if any visible canvas is loading)
- we don't need users to see the loading animation at all if the sketch loads fast enough
- ideally a CSS loader has to be ready to go immediately, if it uses any images they need to be base64 embedded in the p5.js file

> the mouse cursor could also be set to indicate loading when hovering over the canvas that's loading

I loved this idea, this could be great and we should consider a mouse cursor to be also set to indicate loading while hovering the canvas.


I don't know if that's feasible or maybe acceptable by other contributors/members, but what do you feel about just having a loading cursor to show a loading sketch? without any css loader or anything :"). It's just a thought, _**if hovering to the canvas or not**_, if my sketch is been loaded my cursor icon should change and looks like it's a loading cursor. Without any animation on the canvas?

Could be cool to have the mouse cursor become a spinning p5.js asterisk!

Partly I think this issue is trying to solve the problem of having a totally blank canvas (or purely static elements on it) during loading though.

Hi, so I'm a new contributor I'm not yet familiar with the codebase
how can i get this issue assigned to me? do i need to provide basic ideas in advance?

HI @AhmedMagedC welcome! There's a few different ideas here, have you had a chance to check [the earlier comment](https://github.com/processing/p5.js/issues/6795#issuecomment-2809160037) out? From that and all the later comments and ideas, what do you think is most interesting and doable to you? To recap: the 2 options are to write a tutorial or to create an add-on library. The add-on library can explore any of the ideas listed here (cursor override, various loading text, etc), it's an open topic and when the first version is done others can iterate on it.

I think the first one is more doable to me
If i understand the idea correctly, when setup function being async and when the loading takes too long (Or maybe many assets are being loaded ?)
a tutorial is suggested by p5 FES to users showing them how to create their own custom loading animation, so
my responsibility is to write that tutorial and to show that message when the loading takes too long?

Hi @ksen0 and all,

Last week, I took the liberty of putting together a proof of concept based on Kit's suggestions. It includes a randomized list of "Loading..." words in multiple languages, and an (optional) spinning p5.js logo for the cursor. Let me know if that's close to what you had in mind.

The code is available on OpenProcessing here: https://openprocessing.org/sketch/2619980

Thanks to @Stefterv for helping me figure out the lifecycle hooks in p5.js 2.0, and how to use p5.js for the loading animation (instead of CSS).

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/446c7ca8-f759-4a57-90a5-47191b12da60)
@SableRaf, your loading animation is fantastic! The p5-branded spinner and multilingual support make this an elegant solution. Turning it into an add-on could be a brilliant idea

> Hi [@ksen0](https://github.com/ksen0) and thanks for the summary!
> 
> On the tutorial idea, I've updated a 1.x demo sketch of mine for async/await [here](https://editor.p5js.org/SableRaf/sketches/Nb0WPmyI6). It could potentially be used as a basis for a tutorial on custom loaders. I'm curious if that's the direction you had in mind.
> 
> About the loading text idea, I'm wondering if it???s necessary? Visual loading indicators (not necessarily a spinning star) are pretty common, and I think most people would recognize them without text. But I know you had some thoughts about this, so I???m open to whatever makes most sense 😌

Hi [SableRaf](https://github.com/SableRaf),
Thanks for the demo sketch! it could indeed be a good basis to helping writing the tutorial.
but I had an issue running your demo in 1.x versions, the image doesn't display after loading animation is done, when i tried to debug i found that draw function starts immediately, it doesn't wait for the async functions in setup to be awaited
so is this a normal behavior? also giving that it works normally in 2.0.0 version (draw function doesn't start until all async functions in setup is completed)

Hi [@ksen0 ](https://github.com/ksen0), how are you?
Just checking in to inform you I'm still interested in writing the tutorial, honestly I'm also interested in implementing the add-on library, but after finishing the tutorial

# How to approach it?
so after reading through the comments, I think there are two main approaches for the user to create custom loading animation
1. using p5 visual elements to create it like what was mentioned by [@quinton-ashley ](https://github.com/quinton-ashley), also was done by this tutorial [9.14: Loading Animation - p5.js Tutorial](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UWgDKtvnjIU)

2. using CSS to create the animation, taking this [demo sketch](https://editor.p5js.org/SableRaf/sketches/Nb0WPmyI6) by [@SableRaf ](https://github.com/SableRaf) as a strong reference

so should i create new issue on p5.js-website?

also any feedback would be highly appreciated ??????

Hi @AhmedMagedC. I would recommend building on the approach I shared in my latest reply (and [this proof of concept](https://openprocessing.org/sketch/2619980)) rather than the earlier CSS-based prototype. This version is more aligned with p5.js v2.0 (using async/await) and relies fully on p5.js for rendering. It also has the advantage that the loader starts after the p5 canvas is created, so it can match the correct size. I understand the code might feel a bit more complex, but I'm happy to walk through it together if that would be helpful! 

PS: @ksen0 let me know if that approach makes sense to you as well or if you have a different idea

Hi @AhmedMagedC thanks so much for your enthusiasm!

Because the new sketch ([this one](https://openprocessing.org/sketch/2619980)) is much more complete and already reflects most of the current discussion I would agree with @SableRaf that it is the best place to start - and thanks to @SableRaf for both making the example and offering help if any is needed! I think it makes sense to focus on p5.js 2.0 implementation in this issue. This is pretty distinct from the topic of the [the Coding Train loading tutorial video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UWgDKtvnjIU).

@AhmedMagedC given the above sketch, I think the tutorial version of the task can be to prepare a tutorial for p5.js website (in the `2.0` branch / for the beta.p5js.org website) walking through [building this loading animation](https://openprocessing.org/sketch/2619980) step by step, with the aim to help the user understand how this code works, and be able to customize (use different texts, and/or replace the cursor animation with something of their own). @SableRaf and others, does that seem reasonable to you?

You can check other tutorials ([like the get started one](https://beta.p5js.org/tutorials/get-started/)) to see the level of detail here; they are very step by step and detailed. You could work on an add-on library instead or after if you prefer.

(Visually one thing that could be a little different is aligning left-to-right and right-to-left languages [like this](https://openprocessing.org/sketch/2628082) but that's just a thought! I think when tutorial and/or library is ready, it would be cool to invite more "loading" text translations.)

but i have issues making the lib compatible with 1.x , while assets are loading in `preload()`canvas and p5 visual elements are not yet initialized, making it impossible to depend on p5 elements to create the loading animation/spinning logo

so what do you think i should do? 

also another question when it comes to coding best practice, can i use internal p5 variables that was intended for internal use only like `_setupDone` or should i find workaround instead?

[repo](https://github.com/AhmedMagedC/p5.loadingAnimation.js)

Hi @AhmedMagedC , Great work, it looks good! . Could you also share a short demo video like @SableRaf  did? It would help us see it in action. About p5 1.x support: I think you're right that the preload() phase can be tricky since the canvas and visual elements aren't fully initialized yet. Since preload() runs before canvas init, maybe consider a standalone loader outside p5. Also, using internal vars like _setupDone isn???t ideal for stability; it's better to use custom flags, if possible I think.

> Hi [@AhmedMagedC](https://github.com/AhmedMagedC) , Great work, it looks good! . Could you also share a short demo video like [@SableRaf](https://github.com/SableRaf) did? It would help us see it in action. About p5 1.x support: I think you're right that the preload() phase can be tricky since the canvas and visual elements aren't fully initialized yet. Since preload() runs before canvas init, maybe consider a standalone loader outside p5. Also, using internal vars like _setupDone isn???t ideal for stability; it's better to use custom flags, if possible I think.

Hi [@VANSH3104](https://github.com/VANSH3104), thanks for the suggestion
I will surely add examples and docs in my repo when i finish the logic itself

Can you please elaborate more on the idea of standalone loader outside p5?
do you mean to make it depends on CSS ?

Hi @AhmedMagedC , Just to clarify, by "standalone loader outside p5", I didn???t mean a CSS-based one. Instead, I was referring to a loader built with p5.js itself, but initialized after the canvas is created, outside of the preload() lifecycle. That way, we avoid the limitations of preload(). You can see SableRaf solution.

> Hi [@AhmedMagedC](https://github.com/AhmedMagedC) , Just to clarify, by "standalone loader outside p5", I didn???t mean a CSS-based one. Instead, I was referring to a loader built with p5.js itself, but initialized after the canvas is created, outside of the preload() lifecycle. That way, we avoid the limitations of preload(). [@ksen0](https://github.com/ksen0) [@SableRaf](https://github.com/SableRaf), kinda stuck here if you can help! I think i can add CSS-based solution when user works with `preload()` in 1.x p5 version , so what do you think?

@AhmedMagedC We are only looking to implement this in 2.x. 1.x has completely different requirements and we are currently not accepting any new feature to 1.x, instead focusing on 2.x more, so if there is a solution for 2.x already it is good enough for this issue.

summary.main: The main goal of this issue is to replace the text-based 'Loading' message with a visual loading animation that provides a better user experience and enhances accessibility.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires a visual loading animation that is triggered after the `preload()` function has finished loading assets. The animation should be simple and universally recognized. The issue also requires that the loading animation be opt-in or opt-out for the user.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue mentions that some contributors have tried to create a custom loading animation, but it's not clear if they have been successful. The issue also mentions that some users have suggested using a CSS-based solution, but it's not clear if this has been implemented.
summary.otherNotes: The issue aims to replace the text-based 'Loading' message with a visual loading animation. The animation could be a simple, universally recognized loading indicator (e.g., spinning circle) that provides a visual cue to users that content is being loaded without relying on text. The loading animation could be triggered using the `afterPreload` lifecycle event. The issue also discusses the possibility of making the loading animation opt-in or opt-out for the user.

issueDTO.title: migrate IterableNotToContainValuesExpectationsSpec to kotlin-test
issueDTO.description:
*Platform* (all, jvm, js): all
*Extension* (none, kotlin 1.3): none

## Code related feature

We want to move away from Spek as test-runner as we consider this project dead and it makes more and more problems in conjunction with intellij and gradle. Hence, we migrate the tests in atrium-specs to kotlin-test.

Following the things you need to do:

see https://github.com/robstoll/atrium/issues/1963

## Your first contribution?
- Write a comment `I'll work on this` if you would like to take this issue over. 
  This way we get the chance to revise the description in case things have changed in the meantime, we might give you additional hints and we can assign the task to you, so that others do not start as well.
- See [Your first code contribution](https://github.com/robstoll/atrium/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#your-first-code-contribution) for guidelines.  
- Do not hesitate to ask questions here or to contact us via [Atrium's slack channel](https://kotlinlang.slack.com/team/U3DE1TXKP) if you need help
  ([Invite yourself](https://slack.kotlinlang.org/) in case you do not have an account yet).
comments: @robstoll - I'll work on this

@robstoll - Since both `IterableNotToContainValuesExpectations` in fluent/infix contain a BuilderSpec and a ShortSpec and per the instructions in #1963, I need to split the class into two or more, I wanted to ask if there is an example I can see on how to do this?

```
class IterableNotToContainValuesExpectationsSpec : Spek({

    include(BuilderSpecToContain)
    include(ShortcutSpecToContain)

}) {

    object BuilderSpecToContain : ch.tutteli.atrium.specs.integration.IterableNotToContainValuesExpectationsSpec(
        getNotToContainPair(),
        getNotToContainNullablePair(),
        Expect<List<Int>>::notToHaveElementsOrNone.name,
        "[Atrium][Builder] "
    )

    object ShortcutSpecToContain : ch.tutteli.atrium.specs.integration.IterableNotToContainValuesExpectationsSpec(
        getNotToContainShortcutPair(),
        getNotToContainNullablePair(),
        Expect<List<Int>>::notToHaveElementsOrNone.name,
```

CharSequenceToContainNotToContainExpectationsBuilderTest and CharSequenceToContainNotToContainExpectationsShortcutTest

the ambiguityTests in CharSequenceToContainNotToContainExpectationsBuilderTest are wrong, they don't use the builder. Also, they don't re-assign to a1. See https://github.com/robstoll/atrium/pull/2084/files#diff-db8c29ee9cc341e5f206a822ff1f8b636eb2efe8a730feccf78109535e89811eR33 for how it is supposed to be done => which is merged by now, please rebase.
@robstoll - So I don't repeat the errors in the other PR, what is the proper way to rebase when merging?

short version:
```
git remote add upstream https://github.com/robstoll/atrium
git fetch upstream main
git rebase upstrea/main
```

Longer version: https://github.com/robstoll/atrium/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#git

@robstoll - I've taken the changes from main. Just to make sure, I see that for the **fluent** directory, these classes already exist. So I am creating them only for the **infix** directory. Correct?

Also, since the original `IterableNotToContainValuesExpectations` has the companion object, do I just copy it to the CharSequenceToContainNotToContainExpectationsBuilderTest and the CharSequenceToContainNotToContainExpectationsShortcutTest and create an ambiguityTest in each class?

> these classes already exist.

Which classes do you mean? I see that in fluent it was wrongly named IterableToContainNotValuesExpectationsSpec instead of IterableNotToContainValuesExpectations (will be fixed soonish)

Maybe a misunderstanding regarding [my comment](https://github.com/robstoll/atrium/issues/2014#issuecomment-3419966619) about 
> I wanted to ask if there is an example I can see on how to do this?

I mentioned those because before migration they where in one file, also with BuilderSpec and ShortcutSpec.
So in your case you create two new files called:
- IterableNotToContainValuesShortuctExpectationsTest
- IterableNotToContainValuesBuilderExpectationsTest

And yes, each will have its own ambiguityTest
@robstoll - I meant the classes you referred to [here](https://github.com/robstoll/atrium/issues/2014#issuecomment-3419966619). A misunderstanding on my part. Thanks for the clarification.

issueDTO.title: Extend the utility of the `--dev` command by running with dev output by default when SOLO_DEV_OUTPUT environment variable is set
issueDTO.description:
### Feature to Enhance

Enhance the CLI. Specifically around [Using Environment Variables](https://solo.hiero.org/v0.47.0/docs/env/).

### Requested Enhancement

Add support for `${SOLO_DEV_OUTPUT}` variable which when set to a truthy value would treat every solo command as if the `--dev` flag was passed to it.

### Business Need

Provides cleaner CLI scripts and saves key-strokes if you will be running several solo commands want to pass the `--dev` flag to each one.

### Additional Context

Would enhance usability in workflow scripts and improve readability.

issueDTO.title: Prioritize local types when auto-completing in a `-spec`
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the bug

When completing in a `-spec` context, we can potentially return a huge list of atoms.
Local types are lost in that list.

### To Reproduce**

Define a local type:

```
-type my_integer() :: integer().
```

Then start composing a `-spec` attribute:

```
-spec foo(my_in~
```

### Expected behavior

The `my_integer/0` type appears at the top of the list of completions.

### Actual behavior

The type is there, but lost in the sea of all available atoms.

repository.description: Erlang Language Platform. LSP server and CLI.
repository.name: erlang-language-platform

summary.main: Prioritize local types when auto-completing in a `-spec` context, so that the local type appears at the top of the list of completions.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The requirement is that local types should be prioritized when auto-completing in a `-spec` context.
summary.attemptedFixes: No attempted fixes or blockers mentioned in the issue description.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about auto-completion in a `-spec` context, where local types are lost in the list of completions. The expected behavior is that the local type should appear at the top of the list, but it's not.

issueDTO.title: [Docs]: Create deployment guide for Azure Virtual Machines
issueDTO.description:
## 📖 Deployment Guide Request

Create a guide for deploying **InsForge** (open-source BaaS) to **Azure Virtual Machines**.

### 🎯 About InsForge

InsForge is a full-stack application with:
- **Backend:** Node.js + Express + PostgreSQL
- **Frontend:** React dashboard
- **Deployment:** Docker Compose with 4 services (postgres, postgrest, backend, deno)

### 📝 What to Create

Write a simple guide showing how to self-host InsForge on Azure Virtual Machines.

**Guide should cover:**
1. **Platform Setup** - Create Azure Virtual Machines account/project
2. **Database Setup** - PostgreSQL configuration
3. **Deploy Services** - Deploy InsForge containers/services
4. **Environment Variables** - Required configuration
5. **Access** - How to access deployed instance

### 💡 Reference

- InsForge uses Docker Compose: `docker-compose.yml`
- Similar projects: n8n, PocketBase, Supabase self-hosting guides
- Deploy on Azure VM with Docker Compose

### ??? Deliverable

Create: `docs/deployment/deploy-to-azure-virtual-machines.md`

---

Thank you for helping users deploy InsForge on Azure Virtual Machines! 🙏

issueDTO.title: Clean Up Legacy Version References in NGINX Plus Live Activity Monitoring Doc
issueDTO.description:
### Overview

The [Live Activity Monitoring documentation](https://docs.nginx.com/nginx/admin-guide/monitoring/live-activity-monitoring/) currently includes numerous references to features introduced in legacy versions of NGINX Plus???some going as far back as R9 (GA in 2016). Since we only support the last two NGINX Plus releases (currently **R34** and **R33**), these older version references are no longer relevant and may confuse readers by framing standard features as ???new.???

---

### Why This Matters

- Calling out features from 2016 (e.g., ???introduced in R9???) is outdated in 2025.
- Removing legacy version callouts simplifies the content and improves readability.
- It aligns the doc with our support policy and avoids giving unnecessary prominence to deprecated or old versions.

---

### What Needs to Be Done

- Remove specific version mentions that predate the last two supported releases.
- Keep the focus on what???s possible _now_, not what was introduced years ago.
- Review the full doc for consistency and remove any outdated versioning language.

---

### Suggested Edits (Actual Examples)

**1. REST API introduction (R14)**

> ??? _???NGINX REST API available since NGINX Plus Release 14...???_  
> ??? _???The NGINX REST API provides extended status information, server and key-value store management...???_

**2. Superseded modules (R14???R16)**

> ??? _???Note: Prior to NGINX Plus R14... Starting from R16...???_  
> ??? _???Earlier versions used the `status` and `upstream_conf` modules, which are now fully replaced by the `api` module.???_  
Or just:  
> ??? _???The `api` module replaces the older `status` and `upstream_conf` modules for monitoring and management.???_

**3. Swagger UI and OpenAPI spec (R25???R26)**

> ??? _???Prior to NGINX Plus Release 25, the Swagger UI was shipped... Since NGINX Plus Release 26...???_  
> ??? _???The OpenAPI YAML specification and Swagger UI are published separately from NGINX Plus packages.???_

Or more succinctly:

> ??? _???The Swagger UI is no longer bundled with NGINX Plus; it is published separately, below.???_

---

### Resources

- 📄 [Live Activity Monitoring Documentation](https://docs.nginx.com/nginx/admin-guide/monitoring/live-activity-monitoring/)
- 📝 [NGINX Plus Release Notes](https://docs.nginx.com/nginx/releases/)

---

### Impact

This is a small but meaningful update that helps keep the documentation accurate, current, and easier to maintain going forward.
comments:
- Do you want any version numbers listed at all?
- What is the newest version? The section titled [Getting statistics with the API](https://docs.nginx.com/nginx/admin-guide/monitoring/live-activity-monitoring/#getting-statistics-with-the-api) uses version 9 as an example in the URL breakdown.

I think version 9 is the latest version for the API. @y82 -- can you confirm?

NGINX Plus is on version R34 (see [Releases](https://docs.nginx.com/nginx/releases/)). 

Generally, I'd like to avoid referring to _NGINX Plus_ versions (like R34) in this doc, as those references have a shelf life and would require updating in the future.
